{{About||the American television film|Killing Jesus (2015 film)|the Colombian film|Killing Jesus (2017 film)}} {{Infobox book | name = Killing Jesus | image = Killing Jesus cover.jpg | caption = | author = [[Bill O'Reilly (political commentator)|Bill O'Reilly]] and [[Martin Dugard (author)|Martin Dugard]] | title_orig = | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = | subject = [[Crucifixion of Jesus]] | genre = | publisher = Henry Holt and Co. | pub_date = September 24, 2013 | english_pub_date = | media_type = Hardcover | pages = 304 | isbn = 978-0805098549 | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = [[Killing Lincoln]] | followed_by = [[Killing Patton]] }} '''''Killing Jesus: A History''''' is a 2013 book by [[Bill O'Reilly (political commentator)|Bill O'Reilly]] and [[Martin Dugard (author)|Martin Dugard]] about the [[Life of Jesus in the New Testament|life]] and [[crucifixion of Jesus]], referred to in the book as [[Jesus|Jesus of Nazareth]]. It is the follow-up to ''[[Killing Kennedy]]'' and ''[[Killing Lincoln]]''. ''Killing Jesus'' was released September 24, 2013<ref>{{cite book|url=http://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/killing-jesus-bill-oreilly/1114668114?ean=9780805098549 |title=Killing Jesus: A History |author=Bill O'Reilly |isbn=9780805098549|publisher=[[Barnes & Noble]]}}</ref> through [[Henry Holt and Company]]. The book was a commercial success, debuting at #1 on ''[[The New York Times]]'' [[The New York Times Non-Fiction Best Sellers of 2013|bestseller list]] and remaining on the list for 52 weeks. Popular reviews of the book were mixed, with both Christian and non-Christian reviewers faulting the book for its tedious writing and its claims of historical objectivity. Scholars and historians have extensively criticized the book for its inaccurate, politically-motivated portrayal of Jesus as a "[[Tea Party movement|Tea Party]] Son of God", its uncritical approach to [[primary source]]s, its omission of some of Jesus' teachings, and its oversimplified, sensationalist portrayal of history. Like both its predecessors, the book was adapted into a [[Killing Jesus (miniseries)|television miniseries with the same name]] for [[National Geographic Channel]].
==Writing and research== According to ''[[The Washington Times]]'', while writing ''Killing Jesus'', O'Reilly and Dugard found that sources were far less plentiful than for the previous books in their ''Killing...'' series.<ref name="Vernon2013">{{cite news |last1=Vernon |first1=Wes |title=BOOK REVIEW: 'Killing Jesus' |url=https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2013/sep/25/book-review-killing-jesus/ |accessdate=8 June 2018 |work=The Washington Times |publisher=The Washington Times, LLC |date=25 September 2013 |ref=harv}}</ref> They stated that the Internet was "a treasure",<ref name="Vernon2013"/> but complained that the information on various websites was "contradictory",<ref name="Vernon2013"/> that "hearsay was often quoted as truth",<ref name="Vernon2013"/> and that information from one website was frequently shown to be unreliable when checked against information from more reliable sources.<ref name="Vernon2013"/> Bill O'Reilly stated that he believes the book was [[divine inspiration|inspired]] by the [[Holy Spirit in Christianity|Holy Spirit]].<ref name="Guardian"/><ref name="Moss2013"/>
==Synopsis== The book begins with "A Note to Readers" by Bill O'Reilly, which promises, "...this is not a religious book. We do not address Jesus the Messiah, only as a man who galvanized a remote area of the Roman Empire and made very powerful enemies while preaching a philosophy of peace and love." After a lengthy quotation from the conservative journalist [[Vermont C. Royster]], the introduction concludes: "But the incredible story behind the lethal struggle between good and evil has not been fully told. Until now." The first chapter begins with a [[novel]]istic description of the [[Massacre of the Innocents]] from {{bibleverse|Matthew|2:16–2:18|9}}. The remaining portion of the chapter focusses on [[Herod the Great]], the king of Judaea, the politics of his reign, the visit of the [[Biblical Magi|Magi]], and the birth of Jesus. A lengthy footnote at the end of the chapter defends the historical accuracy of the [[canonical gospels]] and their traditional attributions to [[Matthew the Apostle]], [[John Mark]], [[Luke the Evangelist]], and [[John the Apostle]].
The second chapter describes the life of the Roman general and dictator [[Julius Caesar]], his conquests, his seduction by the Egyptian [[Ptolemaic dynasty|Ptolemaic queen]] [[Cleopatra]], and [[Assassination of Julius Caesar|his eventual assassination]]. Chapter Three summarizes the aftermath of Caesar's murder, the [[Battle of Philippi]], the [[Second Triumvirate]], the [[Octavian]]'s defeat of [[Mark Antony]] and Cleopatra in the [[Battle of Actium]], and Octavian's ascension to the title of ''[[Roman emperor|emperor]]''. The fourth chapter returns to the life of Jesus, describing his worried parents looking for him after he has gone missing during a trip to [[Jerusalem]] for the [[Passover]]. It describes some of the politics of [[Judea (Roman province)|Roman Judaea]], heavily emphasizing the idea that the Jews were victims of Roman totalitarian oppression. Chapter Five describes the [[finding in the Temple]] from {{bibleverse|Luke|2:41-52|9}}, the architecture of the [[Temple in Jerusalem]], [[Nazareth]], and the government and political background of [[Galilee]].
[[File:Detail of three disciples on the far left side of the table in Leonardo da Vinci's Last Supper.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|Detail of three disciples on the far left side of the table in [[Leonardo da Vinci]]'s ''[[The Last Supper (Leonardo da Vinci)|Last Supper]]'', who are shown in a [[black and white]] photograph on page 219 of ''Killing Jesus'']]
Chapter Six describes the preaching of [[John the Baptist]], the arrival of [[Pontius Pilate]] in Judaea, the [[baptism of Jesus]], and John the Baptist's arrest. Chapter Seven describes the alleged debaucheries of the Roman emperor [[Tiberius]] at [[Capri]], described by the Roman historian [[Seutonius]], accepting all of them as historical. Chapter Eight narrates the [[Cleansing of the Temple]] from {{bibleverse|John|2:13-16|9}}, Jesus's meeting with [[Nicodemus]] from {{bibleverse|John|3:1–21|9}}, and the beginning of his ministry. Chapter Nine details the calling of the apostles, the [[Sermon on the Mount]], and the [[anointing of Jesus]] from {{bibleverse||Luke|7:36-50|9}}. Following [[Sacred tradition|Catholic tradition]] rather than the gospels, the authors identify the unnamed "sinful woman" in this passage as [[Mary Magdalene]]. The chapter concludes with the [[Beheading of St John the Baptist|beheading of John the Baptist]]. Chapter Ten entails Jesus's conflicts with the [[Pharisees]] and [[Sadducees]] and concludes with a characterization of [[Judas Iscariot]].
Chapter Eleven describes Pontius Pilate's governance of Judaea and Chapter Twelve [[Triumphal entry into Jerusalem|Jesus's entry to Jerusalem]]. In Chapter Thirteen, Jesus cleanses the Temple again and [[Cursing the fig tree|curses the fig tree]]. In Chapter Fourteen, he [[Jesus at the home of Martha and Mary|goes to the house of Mary and Martha]], proclaims the [[Golden Rule]], tells the Pharisees to "[[Render unto Caesar]]", weeps over Jerusalem, and predicts his own death. Chapter Fifteen has the betrayal of Judas and Chapter Sixteen has the [[Last Supper]], the [[Agony in the Garden]], and the [[arrest of Jesus]]. Chapters Seventeen through Nineteen describe Jesus's [[Sanhedrin trial of Jesus|trial]], [[Crucifixion of Jesus|crucifixion]], and [[Burial of Jesus|burial]]. Chapter Twenty-One has the account of the [[women at the tomb]]. The "Afterward" describes [[Sources for the historicity of Jesus#Non-Christian sources|non-Christian mentions of Jesus]], the [[Apostles#Deaths|fates of the Apostles according to Catholic tradition]], as well as what happened to Tiberius, [[Caligula]], [[Caiaphas]], [[Herod Antipas]], Jerusalem, and the [[History of early Christianity|early Christian movement]].
==Publication and sales== Upon its publication, ''Killing Jesus'' debuted at #1 on ''[[The New York Times]]'' bestseller list,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers-books/2013-10-13/hardcover-nonfiction/list.html|title=Hardcover : Non-Fiction Best Sellers List|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2017-01-18}}</ref> and was on the list for 52 weeks.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers-books/|title=Best Sellers List|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2017-01-18}}</ref> ''Killing Jesus'' surpassed the sales of the book ''[[Zealot: The Life and Times of Jesus of Nazareth]]'' by [[Reza Aslan]], a professor of creative writing, which had been published only a few months before.<ref name="Ehrmanlecture"/><ref name="Ehrman2016"/> Of its sales success, ''[[The Washington Post]]'' wrote, "The most popular titles in the Washington area have a distinctly biblical glow: for the second week in a row, ''Killing Jesus'' by Bill O'Reilly and Martin Dugard is No. 1. This is the third in their spectacularly successful assassination series, following ''Killing Kennedy'' and ''Killing Lincoln''."<ref name="Charles2013">{{cite news|last=Charles |first=Ron |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/style-blog/wp/2013/10/13/an-answer-to-publishers-prayers/ |title=An answer to publishers’ prayers |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=13 October 2013|accessdate=2017-01-18}}</ref> Noting the concurrent popularity of other religion-related books, the article concludes, "Publishers have long known that religion sells. Even in Washington."<ref name="Charles2013"/>
==Reception== ===Popular reviews===
In its fall books preview, ''[[USA Today]]'' called it "a suspenseful thriller."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/interactive/2764697/ |title=Fall preview: This season's 30 coolest books |website=USA Today |accessdate=2017-01-18}}</ref> A review of the book by Erik Wemble in ''[[The Washington Post]]'' remarked that ''Killing Jesus'' and its predecessors "may not advance the scholarship on their respective topics, but who'll take issue with millions of Americans getting a quick-read tutorial on history via O’Reilly?"<ref name="Wemble2013">{{cite news |last1=Wemble |first1=Erik |title=Bill O’Reilly and ‘Killing Jesus’: So it is! |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/erik-wemple/wp/2013/11/11/bill-oreilly-and-killing-jesus-so-it-is/?noredirect=on |accessdate=9 June 2018 |work=The Washington Post |publisher=Nash Holdings, LLC |date=11 November 2013 |ref=harv}}</ref> Nonetheless, Wemble complained that the book's writing was full of annoying verbal [[tic]]s.<ref name="Wemble2013"/> In particular, Wemble criticizes O'Reilly's constant countdown of how much time the person he is writing about has left to live<ref name="Wemble2013"/> and his use of the phrase "so it is..." at the beginnings of sentences.<ref name="Wemble2013"/> Wemble calls the phrase a "a four-word clump of throat-clearing mumbo-jumbo"<ref name="Wemble2013"/> and states that another reviewer counted roughly sixteen or so occurrences of it in ''Killing Jesus''.<ref name="Wemble2013"/> Wemble speculates that O'Reilly may have intended this phrase as "a retroactive cliché, a little riff that would sound impressive in a book about antiquity."<ref name="Wemble2013"/>
In the book, O'Reilly and Dugard state that they are only including events that can be proven as historical fact,<ref name="Wilensky-Lanford"/><ref name="Delzell2013"/> a claim which has drawn criticism from both critics of Christianity and evangelical Christians.<ref name="Wilensky-Lanford"/><ref name="Delzell2013"/> A 2013 review by Dan Delzell for ''[[The Christian Post]]'' criticizes this statement for implying that not everything in the gospels can be proven as historical fact.<ref name="Delzell2013">{{cite web |last1=Delzell |first1=Dan |date=1 October 2013|title=Bill O'Reilly's 'Killing Jesus' Spiritualizes the Historical Christ |url=https://www.christianpost.com/news/bill-oreillys-killing-jesus-spiritualizes-the-historical-christ-105658/ |website=The Christian Post |publisher=Christian Media Corp. |accessdate=9 June 2018 |ref=harv}}</ref> Instead, the reviewer insists that everything in the gospel accounts is demonstrably factual and that O'Reilly's selective omission of stories found in the gospels from his book is tantamount to "cut[ting] Christ in half."<ref name="Delzell2013"/> A review by Tim Chaffey from [[Answers in Genesis]] criticizes the book for deliberately omitting several of [[Miracles of Jesus|Jesus's miracles]] and glossing over others.<ref name="Chaffey">{{cite web |last1=Chaffey |first1=Tim |date=20 November 2013|title=''Killing Jesus: A History'' by Bill O’Reilly and Martin Dugard |url=https://answersingenesis.org/reviews/books/killing-jesus-a-history-by-bill-oreilly-and-martin-dugard/ |website=''answersingenesis.com'' |publisher=Answers in Genesis |accessdate=9 June 2018 |ref=harv}}</ref> The same review criticized the book for its "graphic description of sexual activity"<ref name="Chaffey"/> and for portraying [[Mary Magdalene]] as a repentant prostitute, an idea that is not based on the Bible.<ref name="Chaffey"/>
In an article for ''[[Salon (website)|Salon]]'', [[Robert M. Price]], an atheist theologian and self-identified fan of Bill O'Reilly, labels ''Killing Jesus'' a work of complete fiction comparable to ''[[The Da Vinci Code]]'',<ref name="Price">{{cite web |last1=Price |first1=Robert M. |date=4 September 2014|title=Bill O’Reilly's "Killing Jesus" is fiction: Fact-checking the Fox News' anchor's "history" of Jesus's death: A conservative theology professor unearths mistruth after mistruth in "Killing Jesus" and calls a pinhead a pinhead|url=https://www.salon.com/2014/09/04/bill_oreillys_killing_jesus_is_fiction_fact_checking_the_fox_news_anchors_history_of_jesuss_death/ |website=Salon |accessdate=9 June 2018 |ref=harv}}</ref> and states, "There is no sign whatsoever that the authors of "Killing Jesus" have even begun to do their homework here. In the end notes, true, we find a number of book recommendations, but it is revealing that virtually every one of the New Testament and Jesus books mentioned are the work of evangelical/fundametalist spin doctors dedicated to defending the proposition that the gospels are entirely accurate, miracles and all."<ref name="Price"/> A 2015 review of both the book and the television miniseries based on it by Brook Wilensky-Lanford in ''The Guardian'' criticizes O'Reilly for accepting Jesus's alleged miracles as potentially historical<ref name="Wilensky-Lanford">{{cite news |last1=Wilensky-Lanford |first1=Brook |title=Killing Jesus: Bill O'Reilly's film is touted as history. But facts aren't sacred to him: A Catholic self-described "traditionalist," O'Reilly can't be trusted not to confuse religious interpretation with historical fact |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/mar/29/killing-jesus-bill-oreillys-film-is-touted-as-history-but-facts-arent-sacred-to-him |accessdate=9 June 2018 |work=The Guardian |date=29 March 2015 |ref=harv}}</ref> and remarks that, although O'Reilly claims to treat his subject objectively, he "can't be trusted not to confuse religious interpretation with historical fact."<ref name="Wilensky-Lanford"/>
===Scholarly response=== [[File:DoréMaryMagdaleneRepentant.jpg|thumb|upright=1|Illustration of [[Mary Magdalene]] as a repentant prostitute by the nineteenth-century French engraver [[Gustave Doré]], which appears on page 146 of ''Killing Jesus''. [[Candida Moss]] criticizes the book for accepting this portrayal of Mary Magdalene, which is not supported by the Bible or other early Christian writings.<ref name="Moss">{{cite news |last1=Moss |first1=Candida |title=The Gospel According to Bill O’Reilly Jesus was killed because of taxes—that’s more or less the message of Bill O’s new book. Candida Moss on what else the Fox host gets wrong. |url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/the-gospel-according-to-bill-oreilly |work=The Daily Beast |date=27 September 2013 |ref=harv}}</ref>]]
[[Candida Moss]], a professor of New Testament and early Christianity at the [[University of Notre Dame]], criticizes the book for its many historical inaccuracies in two articles written in September and October 2013 for ''[[The Daily Beast]]'' and [[CNN]] respectively.<ref name="Moss"/><ref name="Moss2013">{{cite news |last1=Moss |first1=Candida |title=Five things Bill O'Reilly flubs in ''Killing Jesus'' |url=http://religion.blogs.cnn.com/2013/10/04/five-things-bill-oreilly-gets-wrong-in-killing-jesus/ |accessdate=8 June 2018 |work=CNN Belief Blog |publisher=Cable News Network |date=4 October 2013 |ref=harv}}</ref> Moss states that, although O'Reilly and Dugard do attempt to separate between fact and fiction, they do so inconsistently and accordingly to their previously held beliefs.<ref name="Moss"/><ref name="Moss2013"/> In her ''Daily Beast'' article, she states: "...without a method, ''Killing Jesus'' has all the critical rigor of your local church's [[Nativity play]]."<ref name="Moss"/> She notes that O'Reilly and Dugard accept late, unsubstantiated legends about the fates of the apostles after the period covered by the New Testament as historical fact.<ref name="Moss"/> They also uncritically accept the legend formalized in the fifth century by [[Pope Gregory I]] about Mary Magdalene having previously been a prostitute, which is not supported by the New Testament or any early Christian writings,<ref name="Moss"/> but ignore the statement actually recorded in the gospels that Mary Magdalene was one of the people funding Jesus's ministry.<ref name="Moss"/> They include statements from John the Baptist accusing tax collectors of overcharging people,<ref name="Moss"/> but omit all reference to Jesus's repeated injunctions to "support the poor, orphans, and widows"<ref name="Moss"/> as well as to the saying, "whoever has two coats must share with anyone who has none; and whoever has food must do likewise" ({{bibleverse|Luke|3:11|9}}).<ref name="Moss"/>
[[File:Rubens tribute money.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|''[[The Tribute Money (Rubens)|The Tribute Money]]'' (1612–1614) by [[Peter Paul Rubens]]. One of many recurring criticisms of the book is its portrayal of the [[Pharisees]] as what [[Candida Moss]] calls "self-righteous bloviators", a view which is no longer supported by mainstream scholars.<ref name="Moss2013"/><ref name="Watts2013"/>]]
In her CNN article, Moss cites the example of how they omit the line "Father, forgive them, for they know not what they do", which {{bibleverse||Luke|23:34|9}} attributes to Jesus [[Sayings of Jesus on the cross|as he was being crucified]], because, as O'Reilly later said in a [[CBS]] interview, it is impossible to speak audibly while a person is being crucified.<ref name="Moss2013"/> She then points out that they chose ''not'' to omit the line "It is finished", also attributed to Jesus while he was on the cross, in {{bibleverse||John|19:30|9}}.<ref name="Moss2013"/> Moss suggests that perhaps "there [is just] something about the word 'forgiveness' that sticks in [their throats]".<ref name="Moss2013"/> She also criticizes them for taking everything written by Roman historians like [[Suetonius]] and [[Josephus]] completely at face value, as though these writers were totally unbiased.<ref name="Moss2013"/> She also particularly criticizes O'Reilly and Dugard's portrayal of the Pharisees as "self-righteous bloviators",<ref name="Moss2013"/> stating that modern Biblical scholars no longer view them this way,<ref name="Moss2013"/> and that this portrayal is, ironically, based more on the stereotype of Roman Catholics promoted by [[Protestants]] during the [[Reformation]] and [[Early Modern Period]] than on actual ancient texts.<ref name="Moss2013"/>
Moss states that ''Killing Jesus'''s description of the apostle [[Paul the Apostle|Paul]] converting to "Christianity" is [[Anachronism|anachronistic]]<ref name="Moss2013"/> because, at the time, Christianity was still a Jewish sect and the word "Christian" was not even coined until near the end of the first century.<ref name="Moss2013"/> Instead, she says "the first generation of Jesus' followers lived and died as Jews."<ref name="Moss2013"/> Moss also notes O'Reilly and Dugard's unusual interpretations of various passages,<ref name="Moss2013"/> such as {{bibleverse||Luke|3:17|9}}, which O'Reilly and Dugard apparently interpret to mean that [[John the Baptist]] told the Pharisees that they will either "burn ''or'' be condemned to Hell."<ref name="Moss2013"/> She concludes: "Apart from the methodological problems, the entire book is written in the style of a novel, not a history book. We hear the thoughts of Herod as he orders the execution of the male children of Bethlehem, for instance. It's entertaining, but it's historical fan fiction, not history."<ref name="Moss2013"/>
In an article from November 2013, Joel L. Watts, author of ''Mimetic Criticism and the Gospel of Mark'', calls ''Killing Jesus'' nothing more than "an attempt at agenda-driven drivel produced for the lowest common denominator."<ref name="Watts2013">{{cite web |last1=Watts |first1=Joel L. |date=25 November 2013|title=Review of Killing Jesus: A History |url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/joel-l-watts/review-of-killing-jesus_b_3984134.html |work=HuffPost |accessdate=9 June 2018 |ref=harv}}</ref> He adds, "I wish I had my day back."<ref name="Watts2013"/> In addition to raising many of the same accuracy concerns as Moss, Watts also criticizes the book for imputing post-[[Age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment]] ideas of [[individualism]] to ancient Galileean Jews<ref name="Watts2013"/> and for referring to the [[Sadducees]] (who believed that the [[Torah]] was the only authoritative scripture and opposed the more progressive theology promoted by the Pharisees) as "liberals".<ref name="Watts2013"/> He also criticizes a statement that the canon of the [[Hebrew Bible]] had been established "500 years" before Jesus, when, in reality, many of the books in the Hebrew Bible were not written until after that point<ref name="Watts2013"/> and the canon of the Hebrew Bible was still debated long after Jesus's death.<ref name="Watts2013"/> Watts accuses the authors of being arrogant and dismissive of the opinions of actual experts.<ref name="Watts2013"/> He determines that "they destroy context and literary construction to, and I can only assume this based on the evidence of reading the book, hide the actual message of the Gospels."<ref name="Watts2013"/>
[[File:Tea Party - Pennsylvania Avenue.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|left|Numerous scholars have criticized ''Killing Jesus'' for its anachronistic portrayal of Jesus as an advocate of "smaller government and lower taxes" similar to the supporters of the United States [[Tea Party movement]] (''protest pictured''), rather than the first-century Galilean Jew he really was.<ref name="Ehrmanlecture"/><ref name="Ehrman2016"/><ref name="Moss"/><ref name="Watts2013"/><ref name="Guardian"/>]]
A December 2013 review in ''[[The Guardian]]'' by Selina O'Grady, author of ''And Man Created God: Kings, Cults, and Conquests at the Time of Jesus'', remarks that, "Everyone creates God in their own image, so it's not surprising that [[Fox News|Fox television]]'s aggressively conservative down-home-let's-hear-it-for-the-ordinary-guy talk show host should have created a [[Tea Party movement|Tea Party]] son of God. Jesus, the little guy, is an enemy of the big corrupt tax-oppressing [[Roman empire]], which is itself just a version of [[Washington, D. C.|Washington]], only even more venal and sexually depraved. This Jesus is a tax-liberating rebel who incurs the wrath of the Jewish and Roman powers by threatening their joint fleecing of the people. As a member of the populist right, he is not, of course, in favour of redistribution: Bill O'Reilly's Jesus does not tell the rich to give away their money to the poor."<ref name=Guardian>{{cite news|last=O'Grady|first=Selina|title=Killing Jesus: A History by Bill O'Reilly and Martin Dugard – review: The right-wing talk show host gives us salacious gossip, gory details and a Tea Party Son of God|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2013/dec/18/killing-jesus-bill-oreilly-review|accessdate=17 April 2014|newspaper=The Guardian|date=18 December 2013}}</ref> The same review criticizes ''Killing Jesus'' for its "bodice-ripping treatment of history",<ref name="Guardian"/> stating that the book oversimplifies, sensationalizes, and misrepresents the historical events it purports to describe.<ref name="Guardian"/> According to O'Grady, ''Killing Jesus'' presents the Romans, Jewish elites, and Pharisees as categorically "bad" and "ordinary Jews" as "good", without any background or nuance.<ref name="Guardian"/> O'Grady also criticizes O'Reilly and Dugard for relying almost entirely on the gospels<ref name="Guardian"/> and ignoring the centuries' worth of books written by Biblical scholars about the historical Jesus.<ref name="Guardian"/>
During a Q&A session following a 2014 lecture at [[Dickinson College]] on "Jesus and the Historian", [[Bart D. Ehrman]], James A. Gray Distinguished Professor of [[religious studies]] at the [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]], laughed at his own mention of ''Killing Jesus'', commenting "Bill O'Reilly! ''There's'' a source you trust about the historical Jesus. Hah! Aye yai yai."<ref name="Ehrmanlecture">{{cite web |last1=Ehrman |first1=Bart D. |author-link=Bart D. Ehrman| title=Jesus and the Historian (lecture) |date= 25 November 2014 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Qd7Lanms-gY |time= 1:01:40 – 1:02:30|via=YouTube |publisher=Bart D. Ehrman |accessdate=8 June 2018 |ref=harv}}</ref> In his 2016 book ''Jesus Before the Gospels'', Ehrman was less overtly hostile, merely commenting that O'Reilly is "obviously... not a New Testament scholar."<ref name="Ehrman2016">{{cite book |last1=Ehrman |first1=Bart D. |title=Jesus Before the Gospels: How the Earliest Christians Remembered, Changed, and Invented their Stories of the Savior |date=2016 |publisher=HarperOne |location=New York City, New York |isbn=978-0-06-228520-1 |page=22 |ref=harv}}</ref> In both the lecture and the book, Ehrman implicitly criticizes O'Reilly's portrayal of the historical Jesus as an advocate of "smaller government and lower taxes."<ref name="Ehrmanlecture"/><ref name="Ehrman2016"/> In the book, though, he adds, "It is easy to see how this view of Jesus might resonate with a wide swath of our population today."<ref name="Ehrman2016"/>
==Television adaptation== [[File:Haaz Sleiman 2008 cropped.jpg|thumb|[[Lebanese-American]] actor [[Haaz Sleiman]] portrayed Jesus in the [[Killing Jesus (miniseries)|''Killing Jesus'' television miniseries]].<ref name="Genzlinger"/><ref name="Maglio2015"/><ref name="Tucker2015"/>]] {{main|Killing Jesus (film)}} [[National Geographic Channel|National Geographic]] picked up the television adaptation of ''Killing Jesus'', just as it had for ''[[Killing Lincoln]]'' and ''[[Killing Kennedy]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Nat Geo Adapting Bill O’Reilly’s 'Killing Jesus'|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/nat-geo-adapting-bill-o-430662|first=Michael|last=O'Connell|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=March 25, 2014|accessdate=March 25, 2014}}</ref> In March 2014, it was announced ''Killing Jesus'' was being adapted into a four-hour miniseries, and [[Walon Green]] has been tapped to write and executive produce the project.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://deadline.com/2014/03/national-geographics-killing-jesus-to-expand-to-4-hours-walon-green-to-write-701056/|title=National Geographic’s ‘Killing Jesus’ To Expand To 4 Hours, Walon Green To Write| first=Nellie| last=Andreeva| website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=March 17, 2014|accessdate=December 9, 2014}}</ref> Also returning as executive producers are [[Ridley Scott]], [[David W. Zucker]], and Mary Lisio, who previously produced ''Killing Kennedy''. In August 2014, [[Christopher Menaul]] was attached to direct the miniseries.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://deadline.com/2014/08/christopher-menaul-to-direct-killing-jesus-mini-for-nat-geo-ridley-scott-815800/|title=Christopher Menaul To Direct 'Killing Jesus' For Nat Geo & Ridley Scott|author=The Deadline Team|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=August 7, 2014|accessdate=December 9, 2014}}</ref>
On its premiere airing, the film was watched by 3.7 million viewers, averaging a 1.0 rating among adults in the 25-54 demographic. The viewership surpassed the record previously held by ''[[Killing Kennedy (film)|Killing Kennedy]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/killing-jesus-nabs-nat-geo-785319 | title='Killing Jesus' Nabs Nat Geo Ratings Record With 3.7 Million Viewers | last=O'Connell | first=Michael | work=The Hollywood Reporter | date=March 30, 2015 | accessdate=March 30, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Maglio2015">{{cite news|url=http://www.thewrap.com/killing-jesus-national-geogaphic-channel-tv-ratings-killing-kennedy/ | title='Killing Jesus' Slays Nat Geo Record With 3.7 Million Viewers | last=Maglio | first=Tony | publisher=[[TheWrap]] | date=March 30, 2015 | accessdate=March 30, 2015}}</ref> A review on ''[[Yahoo TV]]'' by Ken Tucker said of the film, "Rendered without much embellishment and acted with firmly controlled vigor, ''[[Killing Jesus (film)|Killing Jesus]]'', a TV adaptation of the bestselling book by Bill O'Reilly and Martin Dugard, is a fine retelling of the story of Jesus Christ as a historical figure. That last phrase is key. O'Reilly and his co-author sought to write only what they considered provable historical facts about Christ. Whether this has been accomplished I'll leave to historians and theologians..."<ref name="Tucker2015">{{cite web |url=https://www.yahoo.com/tv/killing-jesus-review-bill-oreilly-114929414520.html|title='Killing Jesus': Christ in the No-Spin Zone |last=Tucker |first=Ken |date=29 March 2015 |publisher=Yahoo! |access-date=29 March 2015}}</ref> A glowing review by Hannah Goodwin for the [[Christian Broadcasting Network]] praised the film for its authentic-looking set and costumes and called it "a conversation starter".<ref name="Goodwyn">{{cite web |last1=Goodwyn |first1=Hannah |title="Killing Jesus": TV Review |url=http://www1.cbn.com/television/killing-jesus-review |website=CBN |publisher=The Christian Broadcast Network, Inc. |accessdate=9 June 2018 |ref=harv}}</ref> The review suggested, "Presenting Jesus' life and death from a largely historical perspective could open this religious history to wider audiences."<ref name="Goodwyn"/>
A review by Neil Genzlinger in ''[[The New York Times]]'', however, panned the film,<ref name="Genzlinger">{{cite news |last1=Genzlinger |first1=Neil |title=Review: 'Killing Jesus,' Biblical Tale Retold, Softer on Its Politics |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/27/arts/television/review-killing-jesus-biblical-tale-retold-softer-on-its-politics.html |accessdate=9 June 2018 |work=The New York Times |date=26 March 2015 |ref=harv}}</ref> declaring, "It's a costume pageant devoid both of the reverence that has made some previous film versions work and of the intrigue that might provide a secular ''[[Game of Thrones]]''-like appeal. More effort went into the jewelry and headwear than into the storytelling."<ref name="Genzlinger"/> The same review compared the miniseries unfavorably with the book, stating, "The book tried to put Jesus' story in the broader context of the politics and practices of the day, but here the account is largely pared down to the biblical rendition, with Jesus casting out a demon, preventing the stoning of a woman accused of adultery and delivering the touchstone teachings that all Christians know by heart."<ref name="Genzlinger"/>

{{refimprove|date=November 2009}} A '''laptop battle''' is a competitive event for an [[electronic musician]] to match their skills against others. Competition rules limit equipment to a [[laptop computer]] and an external [[pointing device]] ([[Mouse (computing)|mouse]]). Some competitions allow external hardware, usually a single [[MIDI controller]] (this set-up is very similar to those used for [[live PA]]). There are typically three or four rounds, following a single elimination bracket or similar structure. Each round consists of a number of head-to-head matches between two randomly selected participants. Rules vary, but typically the competitors are allowed two to three minutes on stage to play their individual compositions. Stage presence is often a key element for judging, in addition to technical finesse and an ability to engage the audience.
A panel of judges decide which contestant advances to the next round, single elimination style. Usually, there are no restrictions on the type of material performed other than it must be the competitor's original creation. This aids in providing a distinction from DJ battles, wherein competitors play music created by others. Musical genres vary widely, with tendencies towards [[intelligent dance music]], [[Glitch (music)|glitch]], experimental [[electronica]], [[Mashup (music)|mashups]], [[House music|house]], and [[Power noise|technoid]].
Various local and national laptop battles have garnered the attention of electronic music and sound design production sponsors, such as [[Ableton]], [[Mackie]], and [[Native Instruments]]. Sponsor products are often included in competition prizes. Laptop Battles are becoming a worldwide phenomenon with battles organized in Germany, the United Kingdom, Japan, New Zealand, and Italy.
== Formats ==
All formats vary in length of rounds (usually 2–3 minutes) and competition bracket style (single or double elimination). Some battles also include alternating sets by each performer, such as two 2-minute sets each. Mouse and keyboard rules may vary as well, and sometimes will allow for a USB version of the peripheral if the on-board peripheral is disabled or unused on the laptop.
===Laptop only===
This format was used in the 2006 Atlanta Laptop Battle I, II, and III.[https://web.archive.org/web/20070825152852/http://www.zeroplate.com/laptop/2005/09/battle-one.html]
This format only allows the following equipment: *One laptop *One external sound card
===Single MIDI controller===
This format was used for the 2006 US National Finals,[http://www.laptopbattle.org/index.php?x=RULES] the 2006 Atlanta Laptop Battle Finals, and the Laptop Battle UK competitions.
This format has the following restrictions: *One laptop computer *One external sound card *One [[MIDI controller]] *All equipment must fit in a 2' x 2' square
===Exhibition matches===
This format was featured in the 2007 Atlanta Preliminaries I Laptop Battle.[https://www.blogger.com/comment.g?blogID=3739648805299846529&postID=7069418744439527380] It involves two competitors not included in the single- or double-elimination tournament structure, and may include more experienced performers or the judges from the ongoing laptop battle. This format is unique in that the actual sonic material utilized in the battle is limited, and performers have a limited amount of time to create their pieces.
This format has the following restrictions: *One laptop computer *One external sound card *One MIDI controller *All equipment must fit in a 2' x 2' square *Preparation is limited to a specific window of time before the match *Source material is limited to supplied samples, which are not available to the performers until the preparation window

[[Oshkosh, Wisconsin]] | years_active = 1999 to present | founders = Bob Lenz | dates = second weekend of July | genre = [[Christian music festival|Christian music]] | website = {{URL|http://lifest.com}} }} '''Lifest''' is an annual [[Christian music festival]] that takes place in [[Oshkosh, Wisconsin]] at the [[Sunnyview Expo Center]]. Lifest has the slogan "A Party with a Purpose."{{cite news|title=Lifest Gets Ready to Open|url=https://www.thenorthwestern.com/picture-gallery/news/2017/07/05/lifest-gets-ready-to-open/103451822/|accessdate=March 8, 2018|work=Northwestern Media|publisher=[[Oshkosh Northwestern]]|date=July 5, 2017|language=en}} It is one of the nation's largest Christian music festivals.{{cite news|last1=Loohauis-Bennett|first1=Jackie|title=Lifest announces Christian music headliners|url=http://archive.jsonline.com/entertainment/musicandnightlife/lifest-announces-christian-music-headliners-n843eh6-138807339.html|accessdate=March 8, 2018|publisher=[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]]|date=February 6, 2012|language=en}} ==History== Lifest started as a walk/run in 1990.{{cite web|title=Lifest Announces New Additions to Summer Music Festival|url=http://www.24-7pressrelease.com/press-release/lifest-announces-new-additions-to-summer-music-festival-285610.php|website=24-7 Press Release Newswire}} It became a music festival in 1999, and became five days long for the first time in 2006. Starting in 2013, it was shortened to 4 days. It is held on or around the second weekend of July. In 2013, Lifest had an average of 20,000 attendees per day.{{cite web|title=Lifest Christian music festival in Oshkosh starts today|url=http://www.wearegreenbay.com/health-watch/lifest-christian-music-festival-in-oshkosh-starts-today/167875665|website=[[WFRV]]|accessdate=March 8, 2018|date=7 July 2011}} As of 2018, Lifest featured around 150 artists on seven stages.{{cite web|title=Lifest|url=https://www.travelwisconsin.com/events/fairs-festivals/lifest-40150|website=TravelWisconsin|accessdate=March 8, 2018|language=en}} The festival is a member of the [[Christian Festival Association]]. The [[Winnebago County, Wisconsin|Winnebago County]] fairgrounds board approved allowing Lifest to build a $750,000 permanent main stage.{{cite web|last1=Zimmerman|first1=Jason|title=Lifest to expand, as race track's future in Oshkosh now in doubt|url=http://www.wbay.com/content/news/Lifest-to-expand-as-race-tracks-future-in-Oshkosh-now-in-doubt--459222043.html|website=[[WBAY-TV]]|accessdate=March 8, 2018|language=en}} The stage was built on the site of a [[stock car racing]] track which was closed. It was unveiled for the 2018 event. ==Performers and speakers== [[File:Matthew West playing in the rain at Lifest 2014.jpg|thumb|left|Matthew West playing in the rain at Lifest 2014]] [[File:Bob Lenz closing Lifest 2014.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Bob Lenz closing 2014 Lifest]] Musically, Lifest has featured a wide range of groups such as [[Toby Mac]], [[Casting Crowns]], [[Skillet (band)|Skillet]], [[Newsboys]], [[Steven Curtis Chapman]], [[For King & Country (band)|For King & Country]], [[Matthew West]], [[Family Force 5]], [[Kutless]], [[Downhere]], [[Tenth Avenue North]], [[Fireflight]], [[FM Static]], [[Sanctus Real]], [[Building 429]], [[Thousand Foot Krutch]], 4th Point, [[Superchick]], [[Matt Redman]], [[The Letter Black]], [[Needtobreathe]], [[Matt Maher]] and [[Jimmy Needham]]. [[Superchick]] had their first concert at Lifest;{{cite web|title=Superchick Facebook post|url=https://www.facebook.com/superchick/posts/10151800418995540|accessdate=March 8, 2018}} they held at 2016 reunion concert at the venue.{{cite web|title=Reunion Show!|url=https://www.facebook.com/superchick/videos/10154202200985540/|accessdate=March 8, 2018}} Lifest also has speakers and seminars as an integral part of the festival. Speakers have included founder Bob Lenz, [[Luis Palau]], [[John Ortberg]], [[Tony Campolo]], Scott Spencer, Ken Davis, and many more. Lifest has approximately 3000 primitive and electric campsites available. Activities include dodgeball, archery, 5K Fun Run, volleyball, inflatable games, prayer journey and KidZone. Lifest is run by Life Promotions[http://www.greenbaypressgazette.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070716/GPG0101/707160506/1207/GPGnews Girl's death casts somber tone over last day of Lifest]; Bethany K. Warner; July 15, 2007 [[Green Bay Press-Gazette]], Retrieved July 15, 2007 {{Dead link|date=April 2009}} and requires over 1000 volunteers.{{Cite web |url=http://www.lifest.com/multimedia/Lifest%20Fact%20Sheet.pdf |title=Archived copy |access-date=2006-05-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060516123334/http://www.lifest.com/multimedia/Lifest%20Fact%20Sheet.pdf |archive-date=2006-05-16 |dead-url=yes |df= }} ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == {{Commons category|Lifest}} *[http://www.lifest.com Lifest.com] - Official site [[Category:Christian music festivals]] [[Category:Festivals in Wisconsin]] [[Category:Music of Wisconsin]] [[Category:Music festivals established in 1999]]

{{History of Chile}} This is a list of the [[coups d'état]] (both plots, failed and successful attempts and armed conflicts) that have taken place in [[Chile]], during its independent history. The [[1973 Chilean coup d'état]] stand out being the last one as well as one of the most violent and with more far-reaching impact in the history of Chile.
==1780s== #[[Conspiracy of the Tres Antonios]], (1781) – A failed attempt to declare [[Chile]] an independent republic
==1810s== #[[Government Junta of Chile (1810)|Government Junta of Chile]], (September 18, 1810) – A successful coup in favor of home rule in Chile #[[Figueroa mutiny]], (April 1, 1811) – A failed attempt to restore royal power in [[Chile]] #[[1811 Chilean coup d'état]], (September 4, 1811) – A successful coup in favor of [[José Miguel Carrera]]
==1820s== #[[Campino mutiny]], (1827) – A failed attempt to destroy the opposition to the federalist system [http://historiapolitica.bcn.cl/resenas_parlamentarias/wiki/Enrique_Campino_Salamanca] #[[San Fernando mutiny]], (June, 1828) of Pedro Urriola, José Antonio Vidaurre and the ''Maipo'' Battalion.<ref name="Luis Vitale">Luis Vitale, ''[http://mazinger.sisib.uchile.cl/repositorio/lb/filosofia_y_humanidades/vitale/obras/sys/bchi/j.pdf Intervenciones militares y poder fáctico en la política chilena, de 1830 al 2.000] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070617184937/http://mazinger.sisib.uchile.cl/repositorio/lb/filosofia_y_humanidades/vitale/obras/sys/bchi/j.pdf |date=2007-06-17 }}'', Santiago, 2000</ref>{{rp|page=337}} #[[Chilean Civil War of 1829]], (1829) – An armed conflict between conservatives and liberals over the constitutional regime
==1830s== #[[Arauco rebellion]], (1831) of Pedro Barnechea and Captain Uriarte<ref name="Luis Vitale" /> #Rebellion of Cazadores de Quechereguas Regiment, (1832) – Under Cap. Eusebio Ruiz<ref name="Luis Vitale" /> #Arteaga Conspiracy, (1833), – of General Zenteno and Coronel Picarte<ref name="Luis Vitale" /> #Cotapos revolution, (1833), – of José Antonio Pérez de Cotapos #[[Freire expedition]], (1836) – An invasion of [[Chiloé Island]] and failed attempt to depose the government #[[Quillota mutiny]], (1837) – A failed attempt to depose the government that resulted in the death of [[Diego Portales]]
==1850s== #[[1851 Chilean Revolution]], (1851) – An armed rebellion by liberals against the conservative President [[Manuel Montt]] #[[1859 Chilean Revolution]], (1859) – A rekindling of the armed rebellion by liberals against the conservative President [[Manuel Montt]] started in 1851
==1890s== #[[1891 Chilean Civil War]], (1891) – An [[war|armed conflict]] between forces supporting [[National Congress of Chile|National Congress]] and forces that supported President [[José Manuel Balmaceda]] #Several Balmacedist plots, (1891–94) – Planned by Hernán [[de Abós y Padilla|Abos-Padilla]], Nicanor Donoso, Diego Bahamondes, Luis Leclerc, Herminio Euth, José Domingo Briceño, Edmundo Pinto, Manuel and Emilio Rodríguez, Virgilio Talquino and Anselmo Blanlot against the new government<ref name="Luis Vitale" /><ref>[http://familia-padilla.blogspot.de/search/label/2.2.1.1.1%20Hern%C3%A1n%20Alberto%20Abos%20Padilla%20Neil Hernán Alberto Abos-Padilla Neil]</ref>
==1910s== #[[Military League plot]], (1912) – A failed plot against President [[Ramon Barros Luco]]. In September, [[Gonzalo Bulnes]] the appointed leader of the plot, desisted.<ref name="Luis Vitale" /> #[[Armstrong-Moore plot]], (1919) – A failed plot by Generals [[Guillermo Armstrong]] and [[Manuel Moore]] against President [[Juan Luis Sanfuentes]]<ref name="Luis Vitale" />
==1920s== #[[Government Junta of Chile (1924)|1924 Chilean coup d'état]], (September 5, 1924) – A successful coup against President [[Arturo Alessandri]] #[[1925 Chilean coup d'état]], (January 23, 1925) – A successful coup in which [[Carlos Ibáñez del Campo]] and [[Marmaduke Grove]] overthrew [[Luis Altamirano]] to [[Government Junta of Chile (1925)|return]] President [[Arturo Alessandri]] to office<ref>{{cite book|last=Bizzarro|first=Salvatore|title=Historical Dictionary of Chile|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HKV1WRT8ToEC&lpg=PR48&ots=LLjLFYNVGy&dq=Luis%20Altamirano%20Talavera%20coup&pg=PR48#v=onepage&q=Luis%20Altamirano%20Talavera%20coup&f=false|publisher=Scarecrow Press|accessdate=22 August 2013|page=xlviii|isbn=9780810865426|year=2005}}</ref>
==1930s== #[[Little red plane plot]], (September 21, 1930) – A failed attempt against President [[Carlos Ibáñez del Campo]] by [[Marmaduke Grove]]<ref name="Luis Vitale" /> #Fall of Carlos Ibáñez del Campo, 26 Jule 1931, successful rebellion against Ibañez #[[Chilean naval mutiny of 1931]], (September, 1931) – A rebellion in the [[Chilean Navy]] against Vice-President [[Manuel Trucco]] that ended with the fleet being bombed from the air. #[[Norte Grande insurrection]], (December 25, 1931) – A failed [[Communist Party of Chile|Communist push]] against President [[Juan Esteban Montero]] #[[Government Junta of Chile (1932)|1932 Chilean coup d'état]], (June 4, 1932) – A successful coup that resulted in the instauration of the [[Socialist Republic of Chile]], in which [[Carlos Dávila]] overthrows [[Juan Esteban Montero]]<ref>{{cite web|title=The Revolution of June 4, 1932 |url=http://www.memoriachilena.cl/temas/dest.asp?id=larepublicasocialistaenchileel4de|work=Memoria Chilena|accessdate=22 August 2013|language=Spanish}}</ref> #[[Antofagasta coup d'état]], (September 27, 1932) – A successful coup of General Pedro Vignola that resulted in the resignation of President [[Bartolomé Blanche]] and the return to civilian rule<ref name="Luis Vitale" /> #[[Las Mercedes' plot]], (1933) – A failed plot against President [[Arturo Alessandri]]. Commander-in-Cief of the Army, Pedro Vignola called "to resist the Milicia Republicana by any means"<ref name="Luis Vitale" /> #Humberto Videla's plot, (1935) – failed rebellion of NCO's #1936 plot against Alessandri, (1936) – By René Silva Espejo and Alejandro Lagos<ref name="Luis Vitale" /> #[[Seguro Obrero massacre]], (September 5, 1938) – A failed [[National Socialist Movement of Chile|National Socialist]] attempt in favor of [[Carlos Ibáñez]] that resulted in the murder of 59 young party members #[[Ariostazo]], (August 25, 1939) – A failed attempt of Ariosto Herrera against President [[Pedro Aguirre Cerda]]<ref name="Luis Vitale" />
==1940s== #[[Pig trotters' plot]], (1948) – A failed plot against President [[Gabriel González Videla]]<ref name="Luis Vitale" />
==1950s== #[[Línea Recta affair]], (1954) – A failed plot to allow President [[Carlos Ibáñez del Campo]] to assume dictatorial powers<ref name="Luis Vitale" />
==1970s== #[[Tanquetazo]], (June 29, 1973) – A failed coup against President [[Salvador Allende]] #[[1973 Chilean coup d'état]], (September 11, 1973) – A successful coup against President [[Salvador Allende]] (resulting in [[Death of Salvador Allende|his death]]), in favor of [[Augusto Pinochet]]<ref>{{cite news|last=Reel|first=Monte|title=A Chilean Dictator's Dark Legacy|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/12/10/AR2006121000302.html|accessdate=22 August 2013|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=11 December 2006|author2=Smith, J. Y.}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Presidents of Chile timeline]] *[[List of coups d'état and coup attempts]] *[[List of coups d'état and coup attempts by country]]

{{Infobox military conflict |conflict=Lithuanian Crusade |partof=the [[Northern Crusades]] |image= Lietuviai kovoja su vokiečiais.Lithuanians fighting Teutonic Knights (2).jpg |image_size= 300px |caption= Lithuanians fighting Teutons (14th-century bas-relief from [[Malbork Castle]]) |date=1283–1410 |place=Western Grand Duchy of Lithuania, [[Samogitia]], [[Prussia (region)|Prussia]], [[Livonia]] |territory= |result= [[Polish–Lithuanian–Teutonic War]] |combatant1=
* [[Teutonic Order]] * [[Livonian Order]]
|combatant2=
* [[Grand Duchy of Lithuania]] * [[Duchy of Samogitia]] * [[Poland during the Jagiellon dynasty|Kingdom of Poland]] (since 1385)
|commander1= [[Grand Master of the Teutonic Order]] |commander2= [[Grand Duke of Lithuania]] |strength1= |strength2= |casualties1= |casualties2= |notes= |campaignbox= {{Campaignbox Crusades}} {{Campaignbox Lithuanian Crusade}} }} The '''Lithuanian Crusade''' was a series of campaigns by the [[Teutonic Order]] and the [[Livonian Order]], two crusading [[military order (society)|military order]]s, to convert the pagan [[Grand Duchy of Lithuania]] into [[Roman Catholicism]]. The Livonian Order settled in [[Riga]] in 1202 and the Teutonic Order arrived to [[Culmerland]] in 1230s. They first conquered other neighboring [[Baltic tribes]] – [[Curonians]], [[Semigallians]], [[Latgalians]], [[Selonians]], [[Old Prussians]] (see [[Livonian Crusade]] and [[Prussian Crusade]]). The first raid against the [[Lithuanians]] and [[Samogitia]]ns was in 1208 and the Orders played a key role in Lithuanian politics, but they were not a direct and immediate threat until 1280s. By that time the Grand Duchy of Lithuania was already an established state and could offer organized defense. Thus for the next hundred years the Knights organized annual destructive ''reise'' (raids) into the Samogitian and Lithuanian lands but without great success: border regions in Samogitia and [[Suvalkija]] became sparsely inhabited wilderness, but the Order gained very little territory. The Grand Duchy finally [[Christianization of Lithuania|converted to Christianity in 1386]], when Grand Duke [[Jogaila]] accepted baptism from Poland before his wedding to reigning [[Jadwiga of Poland|Queen Jadwiga]] and coronation as [[Poland during the Jagiellon dynasty|King of Poland]]. However, the baptism did not stop the crusade as the Order publicly challenged sincerity of the conversion at the Papal court. Lithuania, together with its new powerful ally Poland, defeated the Order in the decisive [[Battle of Grunwald]] in 1410, which is often cited as the end of the Lithuanian Crusade. The final peace was reached by the [[Treaty of Melno]] (1422). ==References== * {{cite book| first=Eric |last=Christiansen |title=The Northern Crusades |publisher=Penguin Books |year=1997 |edition=2nd |isbn=978-0-14-026653-5}} [[Category:Wars involving the Teutonic Order]] [[Category:Wars involving the Grand Duchy of Lithuania]] [[Category:13th-century crusades]] [[Category:14th-century conflicts]] [[Category:History of Lithuania (1219–1569)]]

The '''Lithuanian Liberty League''' or '''LLL''' ({{lang-lt|Lietuvos laisvės lyga}}) was a [[Soviet dissidents|dissident organization]] in the [[Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic]] and a political party in independent [[Republic of Lithuania]]. Established as an underground resistance group in 1978, LLL was headed by [[Antanas Terleckas]].<ref name=kace/> Pro-independence LLL published anti-Soviet literature and organized protest rallies. While it enjoyed limited popularity in 1987–1989, it grew increasingly irrelevant after the [[Act of the Re-Establishment of the State of Lithuania|independence declaration in 1990]].<ref name=v112/> It registered as a political party in November 1995<ref name=buga/> and participated in parliamentary elections without gaining any seats in the [[Seimas]].
==First political rallies== [[File:Vilnius St Anns church.jpg|thumb|Square next to the [[St. Anne's Church, Vilnius|St. Anne's Church]], where the first protest took place on 23 August 1987]] [[File:Lithuania Vilnius Maironio gatve.jpg|thumb|Monument dedicated to the protest of 23 August 1987]] On 23 August 1987, the 48th anniversary of the [[Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact]], LLL organized the first anti-Soviet rally that was not forcibly dispersed by the police.<ref name=kace/> The event tested the limits of ''[[glastnost]]'' and other liberal Soviet reforms and is often cited as one of the first signs of the Lithuanian independence movement. The rally took place near [[St. Anne's Church, Vilnius]] and attracted some 500<ref name=nyt/>–1,000<ref>Laurinavičius (2008), p. 52</ref> participants. While the police monitored the event and reportedly [[KGB]] agents took pictures and video of the protesters, the speakers were not interrupted.<ref name=nyt/> Demands raised at the event included publication of the Pact, [[Rehabilitation (Soviet)|rehabilitation]] of [[Soviet deportations from Lithuania|those deported into Siberia]], and greater rights to the [[Catholic Church]].<ref name=nyt/> [[Telegraph Agency of the Soviet Union|TASS]], the official Soviet news agency, labeled the event as a "hate rally" and participants as "aggressive extremists."<ref name=nyt/> Other major rallies took place on February 16, 1988, the anniversary of the [[Act of Independence of Lithuania]], and on other sensitive dates from the [[history of Lithuania]].<ref name=ivas/>
==Removal of Songaila== On 28 September 1988, the League organized an unsanctioned rally to commemorate the [[German–Soviet Treaty of Friendship, Cooperation and Demarcation]] in the [[Cathedral Square, Vilnius]].<ref>Senn (1995), p. 40</ref> Activists of more moderate reform movement [[Sąjūdis]] clearly distanced themselves from the event. The protesters were met by police and security forces from [[Minsk]].<ref name=l155/> The peaceful protest soon broke out into a 3-hour riot. The protesters threw stones and bottles at the police, which responded by employing batons. Around 25 people were arrested. When the police suddenly left the scene, the peaceful protest continued for another hour and a half.<ref name=l155>Laurinavičius (2008), p. 155</ref> In the early morning of September 29, policemen beat and arrested a group of dissidents on a [[hunger strike]] near [[Vilnius Cathedral]].<ref name=l157>Laurinavičius (2008), p. 157</ref> The group, under leadership of Algimantas Andreika, protested the treatment of political prisoners. Outraged by such an unprovoked attack, LLL organized a follow-up rally the same day.<ref name=l157/> Activists of Sąjūdis, including its leader [[Vytautas Landsbergis]], not only participated in the rally but also aggressively questioned the Soviet authorities how such an incident fit into the official program of ''[[glastnost]]'' and ''[[perestroika]]''.<ref>Laurinavičius (2008), pp. 157–158</ref> It was the first time that Sąjūdis actively supported and advocated on behalf of LLL. The arrested people were released the same day. In the following weeks the activists called for the resignation of [[Ringaudas Songaila]], the First Secretary of the [[Communist Party of Lithuania]].<ref>Laurinavičius (2008), pp. 163, 165</ref> The calls reached Moscow, which approved Songaila's replacement with [[Algirdas Brazauskas]] on October 19, 1988.<ref>Laurinavičius (2008), p. 166</ref>
==Relations with Sąjūdis== Due to LLL's uncompromising agenda of full independence,<ref name=v111/> the organization did not enjoy widespread support among the skeptic Lithuanian society.<ref name=v110/> More prominent scientists, artists, and other activists joined [[Sąjūdis]] reform movement, which had more moderate agenda and was established with permission from the Soviet authorities. The relationship between the two organizations was complex. While both organizations shared similar goals, LLL was more willing to confront and Sąjūdis preferred to compromise. The League was a "doer" while Sąjūdis was the "talker."<ref name=v111>Vardys (1997), p. 111</ref> Lithuanians abroad described Sąjūdis as "government approved" and LLL as "patriotic."<ref>Senn (1995), p. 20</ref> At first Sąjūdis distanced itself from the dissident organization hoping not to tarnish its good reputation and respectable image. In the public opinion, dissidents were discredited, brought fear of arrest or other persecution, and were seen as people without a future.<ref>Laurinavičius (2008), p. 92</ref> The presence of LLL saved Sąjūdis from the "extremist" label.<ref name=v110>Vardys (1997), p. 110</ref> However, after a violent suppression of one of the LLL's rallies, both organizations grew closer together. When Sąjūdis opted for open membership, dissidents were free to join its ranks and in fact became its left wing.<ref>Senn (1995), p. 43</ref> The League played an important role by marking all more sensitive dates from the [[history of Lithuania]] with protest rallies or declarations thus stirring up suppressed collective memory and revising [[Soviet propaganda|official Soviet versions]] of the events.<ref name=budr/> It also helped to radicalize the independence movement, hastening political reforms and declaration of independence.<ref name=v112>Vardys (1997), p. 112</ref>
==Notes and references== ;Notes {{reflist|2|refs= <ref name=budr>{{cite book| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UJMzpeUHkQcC&pg=PA51 |page=52 | title=Taming nationalism?: political community building in the post-Soviet Baltic States |series=Post-Soviet politics |first=Dovile |last=Budryte |publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd. |year=2005 |isbn=978-0-7546-4281-7}}</ref> <ref name=buga>{{cite book | title=Political parties of Eastern Europe: a guide to politics in the post-Communist era |first=Janusz |last=Bugajski |publisher=M.E. Steven Mark Brown | parents = }} '''Madeleine Duncan Brown''' (July 5, 1925 – June 22, 2002) was an American woman who claimed to be a longtime [[mistress (lover)|mistress]] of United States President [[Lyndon B. Johnson]].{{cite journal|last=Brower|first=Montgomery|author2=Kent Demaret|title=Was LBJ's Final Secret a Son? Madeleine Brown Says She Bore Lyndon Johnson a Child; Now That Boy Is a Man, and He's Demanding His Birthright|journal=People|date=August 3, 1987|volume=28|issue=5|pages=30–35|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20199578,00.html|accessdate=February 6, 2013}}{{cite news|last=Harlan|first=Christi|title=Dallas woman claims she was LBJ's lover|newspaper=The Dallas Morning News|date=November 6, 1982|location=Dallas}}{{cite news|last=Aynesworth|first=Hugh|title='One-man truth squad' still debunking JFK conspiracy theories|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/news/local-news/20121117-one-man-truth-squad-still-debunking-jfk-conspiracy-theories.ece|accessdate=February 6, 2013|newspaper=The Dallas Morning News|date=November 17, 2012|authorlink=Hugh Aynesworth|location=Dallas}} In addition to claiming that a son was born out of that relationship, Brown also implicated [[John F. Kennedy assassination conspiracy theories#Lyndon B. Johnson conspiracy|Johnson in a conspiracy to assassinate President John F. Kennedy]]. ==Background== Brown described her background in her 1997 autobiography, ''Texas in the Morning: The Love Story of Madeleine Brown and President Lyndon Baines Johnson''.{{cite book|last=Brown|first=Madeline Duncan|title=Texas in the Morning: The Love Story of Madeleine Brown and President Lyndon Baines Johnson|year=1997|publisher=Conservatory Press|isbn=9780941401067}} According to Brown, she was raised in a middle-class Catholic household in [[Dallas, Texas]], where her father was a utility company supervisor and her mother was a housewife. She stated that she attended [[W. H. Adamson High School]]. Brown said at the age of 19 she married James Glynn Brown, a [[childhood sweetheart]] and neighborhood [[soda jerk]], whom she divorced in 1955.{{cite news|title=Man claims to be son of Johnson|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=EiNDAAAAIBAJ&sjid=xawMAAAAIBAJ&pg=3426%2C5635046|accessdate=February 6, 2013|newspaper=Altus Times|date=June 19, 1987|agency=UPI|location=Altus, Oklahoma|page=1}} She described her husband as a veteran of the [[United States Marine Corps]] whose "war experiences had shattered his nerves, and turned him into a hopeless, physically abusive drunkard". Brown said that he "was eventually institutionalized in a veteran's hospital for 'chronic paranoid schizophrenia'". According to Brown, she left her husband in 1948 while he was in the hospital, returning to Dallas with her two-month-old son, Jimmy Glynn Brown. She said that she was subsequently hired that same year by [[Glenn Advertising]] and was promoted to [[media buyer]] whose responsibilities including purchasing [[radio advertising]] time. ==Initial allegations: affair with LBJ== On November 5, 1982, Brown spoke at a [[news conference]] held at the [[Dallas Press Club]], alleging that she had an extramarital relationship with Johnson for almost twenty years. She said that the affair began in 1948 after a party at the [[Adolphus Hotel]] in Dallas and lasted until 1967. ''[[The Dallas Morning News]]'' also published the allegations under the headline "Dallas Woman Claims She Was LBJ's Lover", noting that spokespeople for [[Lady Bird Johnson]] and the Johnson family rejected the claims. Brown's statement, in which she said she wanted to "clear the record", came three weeks after published reports of an affair between Johnson and Alice Glass. ==Paternity suit and subsequent allegations: Child with LBJ== ===Paternity suit filed=== On June 18, 1987, Brown's second son, Steven Mark Brown (December 27, 1950 - September 28, 1990), filed a $10.5 million lawsuit against Lady Bird Johnson in a [[Texas District Courts|Texas district court]] alleging that the former [[first lady]] and two friends of President Johnson, Jesse Kellam of Austin and Jerome T. Ragsdale of Dallas, had conspired to deprive him of a share of the Johnson estate.{{#tag:ref|Jesse "J.C." Kellum, president and general manager of the Johnsons' radio and television interests,{{cite journal|last=Wheeler|first=Keith|author2=William Lambert|title=The Man Who Is The President – Part II: How L.B.J.'s Family Amassed Its Fortune|journal=LIFE|date=August 21, 1964|volume=57|issue=8|pages=62–64, 66, 68–70, 72|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZkkEAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PP1&pg=PA62#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=February 6, 2013|publisher=Time Inc.|location=Chicago|issn=0024-3019}} was referred to in newspaper reports about the suit as "Jess C. Kellam".|group="nb"|name="Kellam"}} His suit claimed: "My legal birthrights have been violated and a conspiracy was formed to deprive me of my legal heirship." The suit included an affidavit from Madeleine Brown, alleging that she met President Johnson in 1948 at a social function within a Dallas hotel, then had an affair with him that lasted from 1948 until 1969. According to her affidavit, Ragsdale, a deceased Dallas attorney, was assigned to assist with legal issues regarding her pregnancy and later claimed to be the child's father in order to shield Johnson from negative publicity. Betty Tilson, the press secretary for Lady Bird Johnson, was quoted as stating: "We're convinced the whole thing is made-up, frankly."{{cite news|title=Lady Bird Denies Dallas Man's Claim|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=QZ5HAAAAIBAJ&sjid=fn8MAAAAIBAJ&pg=4864%2C2151856|accessdate=February 6, 2013|newspaper=The Victoria Advocate|date=June 21, 1987|agency=AP|page=2C}} Tilson indicated that close associates of the Johnson family were not familiar with the name "Steven Mark Brown" nor was there any record of correspondence or visitation from him within the [[Lyndon Baines Johnson Library and Museum]]. She also stated that no one she talked to knew Ragsdale. ===Interview with ''People'' magazine === The August 5, 1987 issue of ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' magazine detailed additional claims made by Madeleine and Steven Brown. In the 1940s, the Johnsons owned a radio station in Austin, [[KLBJ-AM|KTBC]], run by Jesse Kellam. Madeleine Brown claimed that she attended a KTBC reception in 1948 while working for a Dallas advertising agency and was introduced to Johnson through Kellam. She reported that Johnson flirted with her during this initial encounter and that she was "dazzled" by him. According to Brown, Kellam immediately asked her to another reception three weeks later at the Adolphus Hotel. It was at that meeting, she said, that her long affair with Johnson began after he invited her up to his apartment in the hotel. Brown said that Johnson insisted the affair be kept secret, and she alleged that Kellam functioned as a go-between who arranged for Johnson and her to meet. ''People'' magazine reported that she claimed her relationship with Johnson was "[[physical intimacy|purely physical]]" and had discovered that he had other mistresses. According to Brown, she told Johnson in April 1950 that she was pregnant and he assured her he would provide for her needs. She claimed that Kellam told her a few days later that she would be contacted by attorney Jerome Ragsdale. Brown alleged that after the birth of Steven in 1950, Ragsdale provided her with "a six-room house for $15,000, complete with a live-in maid", and paid the various charge cards he supplied to her. She said her physician told her that he would note her husband, James Glynn Brown, as the father. According to Brown, she continued to meet with Johnson throughout the 1950s and 1960s. She told ''People'' that for five years, at Kellam's urging, she had a "[[sham marriage|paper marriage]]" to a Dallas businessman with whom she never lived. She said that years after they divorced, she was told by a friend that the man had committed suicide. According to Brown, she was on her way to see Johnson in Austin when she heard about the assassination of Kennedy over the radio, then turned around. She said that a few weeks later Kellam instructed her to meet the new President of the United States in their usual place. Brown told ''People'' that her sexual relationship with Johnson abruptly ended in 1967 after she was badly injured in a car accident in which her son, Steven, was at the wheel. She said she had one last meeting with Johnson in 1969 at the [[Shamrock Hotel]] in [[Houston, Texas]], in which they had a two-hour discussion which she described as their first "real conversation". Brown said that in 1973 Kellam telephoned her to say that Johnson had died. Brown stated that she was hospitalized after suffering a heart attack in February 1987 and, expecting to die, called Steven to her [[deathbed confession|bedside in order to confess]] hiding the true identity of his father from him. According to ''People'', despite the name of his mother's first husband on his birth certificate, Steven had been "wracked by uncertainty" about who was his true father and "had come to suspect a lawyer friend of the family was actually his father". Steven's mother said that she had no love letters from Johnson and that the few people who could corroborate her story were dead. According to Brown, she came forward with the paternity claim to assist Steven in claiming his inheritance. Discussing the purpose of the lawsuit, Steven said: "In a public forum, sooner or later the truth comes out. That's what's important to me. I want my last name changed to Johnson, the way it ought to be." He maintained that he wanted money from the former first lady in order to provide for two nephews. Shortly after the interview, entertainment writer [[Harry Haun]] said that Brown's claims in ''People'' "stirred up such a hornet's nest of book publishers and movie producers that the woman will indeed write a book about".{{cite news|last=Haun|first=Harry|title=Cool Theaters Can't Offset Trashy Movies|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=gkNPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=8wIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7031%2C5788549|accessdate=February 6, 2013|newspaper=The Blade|date=August 5, 1987|location=Toledo, Ohio}} Haun wrote that literary agent [[Scott Meredith]] had been enlisted to handle the book and film rights. ===Paternity suit dismissed=== In 1989, Steven Brown's suit against Lady Bird Johnson was dismissed after he failed to show in court.{{cite news|title=General Who Helped Build Nuclear Force|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=8bUiAAAAIBAJ&sjid=FbUFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2354%2C156754|accessdate=February 6, 2013|newspaper=Beaver County Times|date=October 2, 1990|agency=AP|location=Beaver, Pennsylvania|page=A4}} He died in 1990, at age 39, from [[lymphatic cancer]]. ==Later allegations: LBJ and the assassination of JFK== After the paternity claims, Brown made other allegations suggesting that there was a conspiracy to assassinate Kennedy, including the charge that Johnson had foreknowledge of a plot.{{cite book |last=Benson|first=Michael |title=Who's Who in the JFK Assassination: An A-to-Z Encyclopedia |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4YovjRf2NYQC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |year=2003|origyear=1993 |publisher=Citadel Press Books |location=New York |isbn=0-8065-1444-2 |pages=61, 223, 491 |ref=harv}}{{cite news|last=Rabinowitz|first=Dorothy|title=Character Assassination|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB107714336725933104?mod=googlewsj|accessdate=February 6, 2013|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|date=February 19, 2004|authorlink=Dorothy Rabinowitz}} In 1988, she briefly appeared in investigative columnist [[Jack Anderson (columnist)|Jack Anderson]]'s syndicated program, ''American Expose: Who Murdered JFK'', and said: "In the fall of 1963 I was in the Carousel Club with other advertising people, and [[Jack Ruby]] was saying that [[Lee Harvey Oswald]] had been in the club and he had been bragging that he had taken a shot at Major General [[Edwin Walker]]". Interviews with Brown implicating Johnson also appeared in an episode of ''[[A Current Affair (U.S. TV series)|A Current Affair]]'' in February 1992, and in a 2003 episode of Nigel Turner's documentary ''[[The Men Who Killed Kennedy]]'', titled "The Guilty Men." Brown claimed to have been present at a party in [[Clint Murchison, Sr.]]'s Dallas home on the evening prior to the [[assassination of John F. Kennedy]] that was attended by Johnson as well as other famous, wealthy, and powerful individuals including, [[J. Edgar Hoover]], [[Richard Nixon]], [[H. L. Hunt]], [[George R. Brown|George Brown]], and [[John J. McCloy|John McCloy]]. According to Brown, Johnson had a meeting with several of the men after which he told her: "After tomorrow, those goddamn Kennedys will never embarrass me again. That's no threat. That's a promise."Brown, Madeleine D. (1997), ''Texas in the Morning: The Love Story of Madeleine Brown and President Lyndon Baines Johnson'', Conservatory Press, p. 166. {{ISBN|0-941401-06-5}}{{#tag:ref|Brown provided a similar account on ''A Current Affair'' stating: "On the day of the assassination, not but a couple of hours prior to the assassination, he said that John Kennedy would never embarrass him again and that wasn't a threat - that was a promise."{{cite news|title=Celebrity|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/bostonherald/access/68772275.html?dids=68772275:68772275&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Feb+24%2C+1992&author=&pub=Boston+Herald&desc=celebrity&pqatl=google|accessdate=February 6, 2013|newspaper=Boston Herald|date=February 24, 1992|location=Boston|page=015}}Fetzer, James. ''Assassination Science'', (Chicago: Catfeet Press, 1998), pp. 368-369. {{ISBN|0-8126-9366-3}}}} Brown said that on New Year's Eve 1963, she met with Lyndon Johnson at the [[Driskill Hotel]] in [[Austin, Texas]], and that Johnson confirmed the conspiracy to kill Kennedy, insisting that "Texas oil and ... renegade intelligence bastards in Washington" had been responsible.Brown, Madeleine D. (1997), ''Texas in the Morning: The Love Story of Madeleine Brown and President Lyndon Baines Johnson'', Conservatory Press, p. 189. {{ISBN|0-941401-06-5}}Turner, Nigel. The Men Who Killed Kennedy, Part 9, "The Guilty Men", 2003. Brown alleged that Johnson did not attempt to stop the assassination because he hated Kennedy and had an intense desire to be President. Brown also said that she witnessed Oswald meeting with Ruby in the Carousel Club prior to the assassination, but did not specify how long before the assassination this meeting had occurred. In the years following Brown's allegations, her story has received national attention and several conspiracy authors have cited her claims as evidence of a conspiracy in the case of the JFK assassination. ==Allegations challenged== In November 2012, ''The Dallas Morning News'' published an article by [[Hugh Aynesworth]] describing David Perry's efforts to disprove Brown's allegations. Perry, a former [[insurance investigator]] turned conspiracy [[debunker]], had placed his investigation of her claims on his website in an article entitled "Texas in the Imagination" the previous month.{{cite web|last=Perry|first=Dave|title=Texas in the Morning Imagination|url=http://dperry1943.com/browns.html|work=dperry1943.com/|accessdate=February 6, 2013|date=October 26, 2002}} According to Perry, he and his wife met Brown at a social function a few years after she made her original allegations as to the JFK assassination but did not find her story to be believable. He said he initially decided to investigate Brown's conspiracy claim of Johnson and other notable individuals attending a party at Murchison's house. Perry pointed to evidence placing key figures outside of Dallas on the evening of November 21, 1963, including Johnson (with Kennedy in Houston and in Fort Worth), Murchison (in East Texas), and Hoover (in Washington, D.C.). He said that while Nixon was in Dallas at that time, a writer for ''The Dallas Morning News'' had placed him at a bottlers convention in the downtown area. Investigating the paternity claims of Brown and her son, Perry found a report of the son's dismissed lawsuit against Lady Bird Johnson in ''The Dallas Morning News'' as well as information indicating a prior conviction for Brown on forgery charges. In 1989, Brown was convicted of forging the will of an elderly relative, who had died the previous year, and was sentenced to ten years in prison.{{cite court |litigants=BROWN v. STATE |vol=888 |reporter=S.W.2d |opinion=216 |pinpoint= |court=Court of Appeals of Texas, Amarillo |date=November 17, 1994 |url=http://www.leagle.com/xmlResult.aspx?xmldoc=19941104888SW2d216_11069.xml&docbase=CSLWAR2-1986-2006 |accessdate=February 6, 2013 |quote=}} The conviction was overturned in 1994 when the appeals court determined she had not personally signed the original will. In 2012, Perry found documents indicating that Steven Mark Brown had previously filed another paternity lawsuit in 1979 claiming to be an heir to the estate of Jerome Ragsdale, the Dallas attorney who Brown said had claimed to be her son's father in order to shield Johnson from negative publicity.{{cite court |litigants=BROWN v. CROCKETT |vol=601 |reporter=S.W.2d |opinion=188 |pinpoint= |court=Court of Civil Appeals of Texas, Austin |date=June 4, 1980 |url=http://www.leagle.com/xmlResult.aspx?xmldoc=1980789601SW2d188_1740.xml&docbase=CSLWAR1-1950-1985|accessdate=February 6, 2013 |quote=}} That suit was also dismissed due to lack of evidence. ==Further reading== *{{cite book|last=Brown|first=Madeline Duncan|title=Texas in the Morning: The Love Story of Madeleine Brown and President Lyndon Baines Johnson|year=1997|publisher=Conservatory Press|isbn=9780941401067}} ==Notes== ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://dperry1943.com/browns.html ''Texas in the Morning Imagination'' by Dave Perry] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Brown, Madeleine Duncan}} [[Category:1925 births]] [[Category:2002 deaths]] [[Category:John F. The '''Nine Years' War''' (1688–97)—often called the '''War of the Grand Alliance''' or the '''War of the League of Augsburg'''<ref>Older texts may refer to the war as the '''War of the Palatine Succession''', the '''War of the English Succession''', or in North American historiography as '''King William's War'''. This varying nomenclature reflects the fact that contemporaries – as well as later historians – viewed the general conflict from particular national or dynastic viewpoints.</ref>—was a conflict between Louis XIV of France and a European coalition of the Holy Roman Empire (led by Austria), the Dutch Republic, Spain, England and Savoy. It was fought in Europe and the surrounding seas, North America and in India. It is sometimes considered the first [[global war]]. The conflict encompassed the [[Williamite war in Ireland]] and [[Jacobite risings]] in Scotland, where [[William III of England|William III]] and [[James II of England|James II]] struggled for control of England and Ireland, and a campaign in colonial North America between French and English settlers and their respective Indigenous allies, today called '''[[King William's War]]''' by Americans.
[[Louis XIV of France]] had emerged from the [[Franco-Dutch War]] in 1678 as the most powerful monarch in Europe, an [[Absolute monarchy|absolute]] ruler who had won numerous military victories. Using a combination of aggression, annexation, and quasi-legal means, Louis XIV set about extending his gains to stabilize and strengthen France's frontiers, culminating in the brief [[War of the Reunions]] (1683–84). The [[Truce of Ratisbon]] guaranteed France's new borders for twenty years, but Louis XIV's subsequent actions—notably his [[Edict of Fontainebleau]] (the revocation of the Edict of Nantes) in 1685— led to the deterioration of his military and political dominance. Louis XIV's decision to cross the [[Rhine]] in September 1688 was designed to extend his influence and pressure the [[Holy Roman Empire]] into accepting his territorial and dynastic claims. Leopold I and the German princes resolved to resist, and when the [[States General of the Netherlands|States General]] and William III brought the Dutch and the English into the war against France, the French King faced a powerful coalition aimed at curtailing his ambitions.
The main fighting took place around France's borders in the [[Spanish Netherlands]], the [[Rhineland]], the [[Duchy of Savoy]] and [[Catalonia]]. The fighting generally favoured Louis XIV's armies, but by 1696 his country was in the grip of an economic crisis. The Maritime Powers (England and the Dutch Republic) were also financially exhausted, and when Savoy defected from the Alliance, all parties were keen to negotiate a settlement. By the terms of the [[Treaty of Ryswick]] (1697) Louis XIV retained the whole of [[Alsace]] but was forced to return [[Lorraine (duchy)|Lorraine]] to its ruler and give up any gains on the right bank of the Rhine. Louis XIV also accepted William III as the rightful King of England, while the Dutch acquired a Barrier fortress system in the Spanish Netherlands to help secure their borders. With the ailing and childless [[Charles II of Spain]] approaching his end, a new conflict over the inheritance of the [[Spanish Empire]] embroiled Louis XIV and the Grand Alliance in the [[War of the Spanish Succession]].
==Background 1678–87== In the years following the [[Franco-Dutch War]] (1672–78) [[Louis XIV of France|Louis XIV]] of France – now at the height of his powers – sought to impose religious unity in France, and to solidify and expand his frontiers. Louis XIV had already won his personal glory by conquering new territory, but he was no longer willing to pursue an open-ended militarist policy of the kind he had undertaken in 1672, and instead relied upon France's clear military superiority to achieve specific strategic objectives along his borders.
