{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2016}} '''The Bouvier Affair''' is the name that art commentators have given to a number of international lawsuits that started in 2015, and subsequent events. The lawsuits allege that Swiss art shipper and dealer [[Yves Bouvier]] defrauded his clients by misrepresenting the original cost of art works and subsequently overcharging them. The affair has played out in courts in [[Monaco]], [[Switzerland]], [[France]], the [[United States|US]], [[Hong Kong]] and [[Singapore]]. [[File:Yves Bouvier.jpg|thumb|Yves Bouvier]]
The alleged victims are "high net worth individuals" in the UK, the US, Asia and Europe, most notably Monaco-based Russian oligarch [[Dmitry Rybolovlev]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/monaco/11436640/Swiss-businessman-Yves-Bouvier-arrested-for-art-fraud.html|title=Monaco FC owner Rybolovlev among alleged victims of huge art scam|last=Mulholland|first=Rory|date=2015-02-26|access-date=2018-08-29|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref>
As of early 2018, Bouvier was facing criminal charges in France, Monaco and also in Switzerland after the Geneva Prosecutor opened a new case there. <ref>https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-02-08/bouvier-questioned-by-geneva-prosecutor-over-russian-art-deals</ref>
== Background to the Bouvier Affair ==
=== Prior fraud allegations === Before 2015, Bouvier was primarily known in the market as an art transporter and [[curator]] through his company, Natural Le Coultre, and as a major shareholder and promoter of the [[free port|freeport]] concept.
==== Lorette Shefner ==== In 2008, he became embroiled in a legal case involving Lorette Shefner, a Canadian collector. Shefner's family claims that she was the victim of a complex fraud, whereby she was persuaded to sell a [[Chaim Soutine|Soutine]] painting at a price far below market value, only to see the work later sold to the [[National Gallery of Art]] in Washington DC for a much higher price.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artsjournal.com/realcleararts/2015/03/bouvier-shenanigans-chapter-two-steve-cohen.html|title=Bouvier Shenanigans, Chapter Two: Steve Cohen|website=Real Clear Arts|language=en-US|accessdate=8 January 2016}}
A suit filed by the Shefner family in New York in 2013 named Bouvier as a co-defendant alongside Paris-based Galerie Jacques de la Béraudière. Bouvier strenuously denies the claims against him, arguing that it is purely circumstantial and not based on any solid evidence. His lawyers have argued that there is no case to answer. The case remains pending.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://cases.justia.com/new-york/other-courts/2013-ny-slip-op-32934-u.pdf?ts=1385072189|title=Shefner v Jacques de la Beraudiere|website=Cases.justia.com|accessdate=8 January 2016}}</ref> Although Bouvier is not the primary defendant, court documents from 2013 accuse him of having acted "in concert" with several experts "to disguise the true ownership" of pieces of art in order to defraud the Shefner estate.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cases.justia.com/new-york/other-courts/2013-ny-slip-op-32934-u.pdf?ts=1385072189|title=Shefner v Jacques de la Beraudiere|last=|first=|date=|website=Justicia|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=30 August 2018}}</ref>
==== Wolfgang Beltracchi forgery scandal ==== In 2013, it was revealed that Bouvier was implicated in the notorious case of [[Wolfgang Beltracchi]], a German [[Art forgery|forger]] who was convicted in 2011 of having defrauded a number of collectors, including [[Daniel Filipacchi]], of millions of dollars.<ref>{{Cite news|title = The $7 Million Fake: Forgery Scandal Embarrasses International Art World|url = http://www.spiegel.de/international/zeitgeist/the-7-million-fake-forgery-scandal-embarrasses-international-art-world-a-768195-2.html|newspaper =[[Der Spiegel]] |publisher=Spiegel Online|date = 13 June 2011|access-date = 8 January 2016|first = Sven|last = Röbel|first2 = Michael|last2 = Sontheimer}}</ref> According to German daily Die Zeit, Bouvier founded in 2008 Galerie Jacques de la Béraudière together with art dealer Jacques de la Béraudière, who played a key role in the Beltracchi scandal.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.zeit.de/2013/18/kunstmarkt-steueroase-yves-bouvier/seite-2|title=Steueroase: Freihäfen seien keine Schmuggler-Höhlen, beteuert Bouvier|work=ZEIT ONLINE|access-date=2018-08-30|language=de}}</ref> This and his ownership of an off-shore entity called Diva Fine Arts led to Bouvier also being connected to the Beltracchi case. He has, however, always denied any connection to Beltracchi and dismissed media coverage as uninformed speculation.<ref>{{cite web|title = Steueroase: Freihäfen seien keine Schmuggler-Höhlen, beteuert Bouvier|url = http://www.zeit.de/2013/18/kunstmarkt-steueroase-yves-bouvier|newspaper=[[ZEIT]] ONLINE|accessdate = 8 January 2016}}</ref> [[File:DmitryRybolovlev1.JPG|thumb|[[Dmitry Rybolovlev]]]]
==== Catherine Hutin-Blay ==== In March 2015, Catherine Hutin-Blay, the step daughter of [[Pablo Picasso]] from his second wife Jacqueline, filed a complaint alleging that 58 separate works had been stolen from her. Hutin-Blay alleged that the works were stolen from a store in a suburb of Paris that is run by Art Transit, a Bouvier family company.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/arts/article/2015/09/15/l-homme-d-affaires-yves-bouvier-mis-en-examen-pour-recel-de-deux-picasso-voles_4757968_1655012.html|title=L’homme d’affaires Yves Bouvier mis en examen pour recel de deux Picasso volés|last=Bellet|first=Harry|newspaper=[[Le Monde]]|access-date=8 January 2016|publisher=Le Monde.fr|language=fr|issn=1950-6244}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/24/arts/design/the-billionaire-the-picassos-and-a-30-million-gift-to-shame-a-middleman.html|title=The Billionaire, the Picassos and a $30 Million Gift to Shame a Middleman|last=Carvajal|first=Doreen|date=23 September 2015|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=8 January 2016|last2=Bowley|first2=Graham|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> It later emerged that Bouvier had sold two of the allegedly stolen Picasso paintings to Rybolovlev in 2013.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2016/02/08/the-bouvier-affair|title=The Art-World Insider Who Went Too Far|work=The New Yorker|access-date=2018-08-30|language=en-US}}</ref> Rybolovlev handed over the paintings to French authorities in 2015.<ref name="Guardian-Ryobolev-returns-paintings">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2015/sep/25/russian-billionaire-picassos-art-dealer-feud|title=so Russian billionaire in art dealer feud hands over Picassos|last1=AFP|accessdate=3 February 2016|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]}}</ref>
Bouvier denied any involvement in the thefts, but in September 2015 he was indicted by French authorities on charges of theft in relation to the discovery of two of the works by Picasso that Hutin-Blay alleged were stolen from her.<ref name="Telegraph-Bouvier-Charged">{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/france/11865015/Yves-Bouvier-charged-over-concealed-theft-of-Picasso-paintings.html|title=Yves Bouvier charged over 'concealed theft' of Picasso paintings|last1=Samuel|first1=Henry|accessdate=3 February 2016|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]}}</ref> In court, Bouvier produced a document meant to certify that he paid Hutin-Blay for the two paintings, to the tune of $8 million, to a fund in [[Liechtenstein]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.parismatch.com/Actu/Societe/Affaire-Rybolovlev-enquete-sur-Catherine-Hutin-et-revelations-exclusives-1362968|title=Affaire Rybolovlev : une héritière de Picasso liée au scandale. Révélations exclusives|last=Match|first=Paris|access-date=2018-08-30|language=fr-FR}}</ref> Hutin-Blay has disputed this, arguing that the payment concerned a matter unrelated to the thefts.<ref name=":0" />
Following several rounds of interviews with lawyers in Geneva, the case was dismissed in 2015,<ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=https://www.tdg.ch/economie/Vaduz-classe-une-plainte-pour-blanchiment-visant-Yves-Bouvier/story/29735335|title=Vaduz classe une plainte pour blanchiment visant Yves Bouvier|work=tdg.ch/|access-date=2018-08-30}}</ref> but reopened in 2016 as Bouvier's associate Olivier Thomas came under renewed scrutiny.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.artnet.com/art-world/dealer-investigated-evidence-stolen-picassos-yves-bouvier-552458|title=New Evidence in Stolen Picassos Case - artnet News|date=2016-07-12|work=artnet News|access-date=2018-08-30|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Allegations of money laundering === In late 2015, it emerged that Bouvier has been investigated by the authorities in Liechtenstein on suspicion of money laundering, in one instance related to a forged [[Max Ernst]] work, that is alleged to have been created by Wolfgang Beltracchi. However, Liechtenstein suspended its investigation in December 2015.<ref name=":5" />
In September 2017, Bouvier was under criminal investigation by Swiss authorities amid allegations that he may have evaded more than 100 million Euros in taxes related to his cross-border art dealings.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.artnet.com/art-world/yves-bouvier-swiss-tax-charges-1072205|title=Swiss Authorities Investigate 'Freeport King' Yves Bouvier for More Than $100 Million in Back Taxes|date=2017-09-06|work=artnet News|access-date=2018-09-03|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Case == The Hutin-Blay case coincided with a separate case involving allegations made by Rybolovlev that forms the main part of the Yves Bouvier Affair. With the help of Yves Bouvier, Dmitry Rybolovlev accumulated one of the most spectacular art collections of modern times since 2003.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-05-31/art-world-s-1-billion-question-was-russian-a-victim-or-savant|title=Art’s $1 Billion Question: Was Russian a Victim or Savant?|last=Miller|first=Hugo|date=31 May 2016|website=Bloomberg|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Rybolovlev's art collection includes paintings by [[Paul Gauguin]], [[Auguste Rodin]], [[Amedeo Modigliani]] ''(Nude on a Blue Cushion)'', Pablo Picasso, [[Henri Matisse]], and [[Mark Rothko]] ''(No. 6)''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vanityfair.fr/actualites/articles/dmitry-rybolovlev-contre-yves-bouvier-le-piege-de-loligarque/27575#|title=Oligarque contre marchand d'art : révélations sur l'affaire qui faut trembler Monaco et la Suisse|last=Gattegno|first=Hervé|work=Vanity Fair|access-date=2018-08-30|language=fr}}</ref>
=== Monaco ===
==== Arrest ==== On 25 February 2015, Bouvier was indicted in Monaco on charges of fraud and complicity in money laundering.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.businesstimes.com.sg/consumer/freeport-king-fails-in-appeal-against-monaco-criminal-charges-0|title=Freeport king fails in appeal against Monaco criminal charges|last=Ui-Hoon|first=Cheah|work=The Business Times|access-date=2018-08-30|language=en}}</ref> The charges followed a criminal complaint made by Rybolovlev's [[family trust]] alleging that Bouvier had systematically overcharged it over a period of 10 years to acquire paintings.<ref name="New-Yorker-Bouvier-affair">{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2016/02/08/the-bouvier-affair|title=A Reporter At Lage: The Bouvier Affair|last1=Knight|first1=Sam|accessdate=3 February 2016|journal=[[The New Yorker]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title = The Billionaire, the Dealer, and the $186 Million Rothko|url = https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-04-27/a-186-million-rothko-pits-russian-tycoon-against-art-merchant |work=[[Bloomberg Businessweek]] |publisher= Bloomberg.com|accessdate = 8 January 2016|first = Stephanie Baker StephaniBaker Hugo Miller|last = hugodmiller}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title = Steve Cohen's Modigliani In The Middle Of An Art Market War: Billionaire Rybolovlev vs Yves Bouvier|url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/afontevecchia/2015/03/12/steve-cohens-modigliani-in-the-middle-of-an-art-market-war-billionaire-rybolovlev-vs-yves-bouvier/|work =[[Forbes]]|accessdate = 8 January 2016}}</ref> Specifically, the Russian billionaire's lawyers accused Bouvier of having misrepresented his role in obtaining 38 art pieces for $2 billion and having thus defrauded Rybolovlev to the tune of a little more than $1 billion,<ref name=":1" /> using offshore companies to disguise his gains.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/afontevecchia/2015/03/12/steve-cohens-modigliani-in-the-middle-of-an-art-market-war-billionaire-rybolovlev-vs-yves-bouvier/#44420da65bd2|title=Steve Cohen's Modigliani In The Middle Of An Art Market War: Billionaire Rybolovlev vs Yves Bouvier|last=Fontevecchia|first=Agustino|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-08-30|language=en}}</ref>
==== Subsequent developments ==== After [[HSBC]] Monaco provided a letter during the police investigation that erroneously stated that Bouvier and a co-defendant, Tania Rappo, with whom he is accused to have conspired to launder money from his art deal proceeds, held joint accounts at the bank, Bouvier called for an investigation into that matter.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/russian-billionaires-battle-with-art-dealer-draws-in-hsbc-1447971694|title=Russian Billionaire’s Battle With Art Dealer Draws In HSBC|last=Letzing|first=John|date=2015-11-20|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2018-08-31|last2=Colchester|first2=Max|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}}</ref> HSBC stated the error was "unintentional and clerical."<ref name=":2" />
Allegations occurred in the French and Swiss press that Rybolovlev received help in arresting Bouvier from Monaco's justice minister, [[Philippe Narmino]], and Jean-Pierre Dreno, the state prosecutor.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://artdaily.com/news/82863/Monaco-gives-go-ahead-to-million-dollar-art-fraud-trial-between-Dmitry-Rybolovlev-and-Yves-Bouvier--#.W4luC5P7RTZ|title=Monaco gives go-ahead to million-dollar art fraud trial between Dmitry Rybolovlev and Yves Bouvier|last=Villarreal|first=Ignacio|website=artdaily.com|language=en|access-date=2018-08-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.tdg.ch/economie/vaduz-classe-plainte-blanchiment-visant-yves-bouvier/story/29735335|title=Vaduz classe une plainte pour blanchiment visant Yves Bouvier|work=tdg.ch/|access-date=2018-08-31}}</ref> On that basis, Bouvier and Rappo attempted to have the charges against them thrown out in November 2015, arguing that there were a number of irregularities in the legal procedure against them and that Rybolovlev may have exercised undue influence.<ref name=":3">{{cite web|title = Freeport king fails in appeal against Monaco criminal charges|url = http://www.businesstimes.com.sg/consumer/freeport-king-fails-in-appeal-against-monaco-criminal-charges-0|newspaper=[[Business Times (Singapore)|The Business Times]] |accessdate = 8 January 2016}}</ref> However, the judge rejected their argument.<ref name=":3" /> Criminal proceedings are ongoing as of 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-02-08/bouvier-questioned-by-geneva-prosecutor-over-russian-art-deals|title=Art Dealer Quizzed After Billionaire’s Fraud Complaint|last=|first=|date=|website=Bloomberg|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=31 August 2018}}</ref>
=== Singapore === On 12 March 2015, Rybolovlev sued Bouvier in [[Singapore]], asking for a global freeze on Bouvier's and Rappo's assets.<ref name=":1" /> On 13 March, Senior Judge Lai Siu Chiu of the High Court of Singapore ordered the global freezing of Bouvier's assets.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-singapore-court-idUSKBN0M90RH20150313|title=Singapore court orders asset freeze on 'Freeport King'|date=13 March 2017|newspaper=Reuters|access-date=3 November 2016}}</ref> The Singapore Court of Appeal repealed the decision and ordered that Bouvier's assets be unfrozen, citing a low risk that Bouvier would dissipate his assets and that Rybolovlev failed to follow procedure in the injunction by not giving Bouvier notice of the proceedings.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.artnet.com/art-world/singapore-unfreezes-yves-bouviers-assets-327141|title=Singapore Court Unfreezes Bouvier's Assets - artnet News|date=2015-08-25|work=artnet News|access-date=2018-08-31|language=en-US}}</ref>
In March 2016, the High Court of Singapore dismissed Bouvier's attempt to suspend the civil suit filed in the territory against him by two companies linked to the Rybolovlev family trust. Bouvier had argued the dispute should be fought in the Swiss courts.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/spore-court-to-hear-14b-art-suit|title=Singapore court to hear $1.4b art suit|last=hermes|access-date=26 March 2016|newspaper=[[The Straits Times]]}}</ref> In a judgment published on 22 March 2016, Senior Judge Lai Siu Chiu ruled that the Singapore suit, which was filed in the High Court in 2015, should proceed. She said the case should be transferred to the Singapore International Commercial Court, which deals specifically with cross-border commercial disputes.<ref name=":4" />
On 18 April 2017, the Court of Appeal of Singapore again contradicted the High Court, ruling that Switzerland was a more appropriate forum for the civil lawsuit.<ref name="theartnespaper.com">{{Cite news|url=http://theartnewspaper.com/news/yves-bouvier-clears-legal-hurdle-in-singapore|title=Yves Bouvier clears legal hurdle in Singapore|date=19 April 2017|newspaper=The Art Newspaper|access-date=25 November 2017|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-04-19/russian-billionaire-loses-a-path-in-fight-with-free-port-king|title=Terms of Service Violation|website=www.bloomberg.com|access-date=2018-08-31}}</ref>
=== Hong Kong === Next to Singapore, Bouvier also had the assets of his [[Hong Kong]]-based company Mei Invest Limited frozen through an injunction in July 2015.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.artnet.com/exhibitions/bouvier-emails-art-transactions-285751|title=Swiss Newspaper Gets Bouvier's Revealing Emails - artnet News|date=2015-04-08|work=artnet News|access-date=2018-08-31|language=en-US}}</ref> In September that year, it was announced that a consent summons had been agreed upon between Bouvier and Accent Delight International Limited as well as Xitrans Finance Limited, two of Rybolovlev's companies. Subsequently, Bouvier's assets were unfrozen.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/law-crime/article/1855225/swiss-art-dealer-accused-raking-us1b-secret-profits-sales|title=Swiss art dealer's Hong Kong assets unfrozen amid court battle with Russian tycoon who accused him of swindling|work=South China Morning Post|access-date=2018-08-31|language=en}}</ref>
=== United States === In New York, auction house Sotheby's got embroiled in the legal dispute in 2016 when the art dealers that had originally sold Da Vinci's [[Salvator Mundi (Leonardo)|Salvator Mundi]] painting to Bouvier, learned that he had sold it to Rybolovlev at a much higher price. According to court papers, Sotheby's was asked to clarify whether it had been aware that the painting was worth more than what the art dealers had sold it to Bouvier for, and whether the auction house had misled the dealers in favor of the Swiss trader.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/28/arts/design/sothebys-tries-to-block-suit-over-a-leonardo-sold-and-resold-at-a-big-markup.html|title=Sotheby’s Tries to Block Suit Over a Leonardo Sold and Resold at a Big Markup|access-date=2018-08-31|language=en}}</ref>
In November that year, [[Sotheby's]] issued a pre-emptive suit in relation to the Salvator Mundi painting, denying that it had ever been part of a scheme allegedly perpetrated by Bouvier to defraud both the sellers of the painting, and Rybolovlev.<ref>https://news.artnet.com/art-world/sothebys-bouvier-rybolovlev-758348</ref>
On 11 June 2018, the US District Court in [[New York City|New York]] granted Rybolovlev permission to access Sotheby's paperwork regarding its interactions with Bouvier for his ongoing lawsuits against the Swiss in Monaco and Switzerland.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.artnet.com/art-world/rybolovlev-bouvier-lawsuit-sothebys-1306292|title=Russian Billionaire Rybolovlev Wins Access to a Trove of Confidential Documents in His Ongoing Crusade Against Yves Bouvier {{!}} artnet News|date=2018-06-21|work=artnet News|access-date=2018-08-31|language=en-US}}</ref>
Another ongoing US investigation into Bouvier and his alleged involvement in fraudulent activities was dropped in May 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/amp/news/articles/2018-05-29/russian-s-da-vinci-windfall-undercut-u-s-probe-of-art-dealer?__twitter_impression=true|title=Russian’s Da Vinci Windfall Undercut U.S. Probe of Art Dealer|last=Berthelsen|first=Christian|date=|website=Bloomberg|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=31 August 2018}}</ref>
On 2 October 2018, Rybolovlev sued Sotheby's for $380 million, alleging the auction house had "materially assisted the largest art fraud in history" and that Sotheby's "knowingly and intentionally made the fraud possible" because it was aware of how much Bouvier had paid the original sellers of the paintings later purchased by Rybolovlev.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-10-02/billionaire-rybolovlev-slaps-sotheby-s-with-380-million-lawsuit|title=Billionaire Slaps Sotheby's With $380 Million Lawsuit|last=Kazakina|first=Katya|date=3 October 2018|website=Bloomberg|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Sotheby's called these allegations "baseless" and told ''[[Reuters]]'' it would seek to have the lawsuit dismissed in a New York court.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-art-sotheby-s-rybolovlev/russian-tycoon-sues-sothebys-for-380-million-over-art-deals-idUSKCN1MD1Y1|title=Russian tycoon sues Sotheby's for $380 million over art deals|last=Devitt|first=Polina|work=U.S.|access-date=2018-10-04|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Impact of the Bouvier Affair == The Bouvier Affair has been widely reported and followed across the art world and beyond as one of the biggest scandals in the sector to date as it laid bare "the exploitation of art for financial gain"<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://newrepublic.com/article/147192/modern-art-serves-rich|title=How Modern Art Serves the Rich|work=The New Republic|access-date=2018-08-29|language=en-US}}</ref> and put a spotlight on the often ethically blurry business behaviors of middlemen in the notoriously opaque art market.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-02-07/geneva-free-ports-king-mulls-art-fight-s-nearly-1-billion-toll|title=Terms of Service Violation|website=www.bloomberg.com|access-date=2018-08-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2015/03/13/art-scandal-threatens-to-expose-mass-fraud-in-global-art-market.html|title=Art scandal may expose mass fraud in art market|last=Frank|first=Robert|date=2015-03-13|work=CNBC|access-date=2018-08-29}}</ref>
Commentators have opined that the unfolding events could be the catalyst for a renewed push to reform the art sector,<ref>{{cite web|title = Does the art market need more regulation? - Apollo Magazine|url = http://www.apollo-magazine.com/does-the-art-market-need-more-regulation/|website=Apollo-magazine.com|accessdate = 8 January 2016|language = en-US}}</ref> for example, through the introduction of guarantees for vendors of highly valued works of art. Furthermore, the private art sales market is expected to take a hit following the public exposure of the scandal.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theartnewspaper.com/analysis/what-will-2018-hold-for-the-art-market|title=What will 2018 hold for the art market?|website=www.theartnewspaper.com|access-date=2018-08-29}}</ref>

{{Italic title}} '''''The Francis Bacon Opera''''' is a comic [[chamber opera]] in one act composed by [[Stephen Crowe (composer)|Stephen Crowe]]. The [[libretto]] is based on Crowe's transcript of [[Melvyn Bragg]]'s interview with the British artist [[Francis Bacon (artist)|Francis Bacon]], filmed for ''[[The South Bank Show]]'' in 1985. The opera was first performed in its final version on 8 August 2012 in London, and went on to win the Hilton Edwards Award in May 2013. ==Background and performance history== The opera is scored for two solo singers ([[tenor]]s) and a piano, and has a running time of 55 minutes. The libretto is derived from three portions of a documentary devoted to Francis Bacon which was filmed in 1985 for ''[[The South Bank Show]]''. In the episode, Melvin Bragg interviewed Bacon over a lengthy wine-fuelled lunch in a London restaurant. Bragg later recalled:
When Francis Bacon and myself appeared on the ''Southbank Show'' and for a few minutes were caught in a state of naked inebriation, it provided I think, an insight into Francis as a man and as a painter. So I left it in the film.Bragg, Melvyn (2010). ''The South Bank Show: Final Cut'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=rNdaRKqOU18C&pg=PT266&lpg=PT266&dq=francis+bacon+south+bank+show+1985&source=bl&ots=nEAlOnOOAa&sig=XS6K1Tdsba8-Pnlxq66cCnOjTu8&hl=en&sa=X&ei=-KcwUZywI-Wa0QXy2oDoCQ&redir_esc=y Chapter 8: "Francis Bacon (1985)"]. Hachette UK
''The Francis Bacon Opera'' was performed as "a work in progress" at the [[Grimeborn|Grimeborn Opera Festival]] in 2011.McDonnell, Keith (15 August 2011), [http://www.whatsonstage.com/news/theatre/opera/E8831313395243/Grimeborn+returns+to+the+Arcola+Theatre+.html "Grimeborn returns to the Arcola Theatre"].[[whatsonstage.com]]. Retrieved 1 March 2013, The final version of the opera, directed by the composer, was first performed on 8 August 2012 at the [[Camden Arts Centre]], London, with subsequent performances at the [[Courtauld Gallery]], [[Tête à Tête (opera company)|Tête à Tête Opera Festival]], the [[Edinburgh Fringe]], [[The James Joyce Centre]], [[National Portrait Gallery, London|The National Portrait Gallery]] and The [[Hugh Lane Gallery]], which houses Bacon's studio, having been relocated from London to Dublin in 2001.Tanner, Michael (25 August 2012). [http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-2741595171.html "Opera Four play"]. ''[[The Spectator]]''. Retrieved 1 March 2013 via [[Highbeam Research]] {{subscription}} ==Roles and premiere cast== *Francis Bacon ([[tenor]]) – created by [[Christopher Killerby]] *Melvyn Bragg (tenor) – created by [[Oliver Brignall]] The pianist for the premiere performance was Genevieve Ellis. ==Critical reception== Performances have polarised critics. Anna Picard in ''[[The Independent]]'' praised the work as having "the rare quality of making people laugh with the music as much as the words",Picard, Anna (12 August 2012). [https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/classical/reviews/lheure-espagnole-lenfant-et-les-sortilges-glyndebourne-east-sussextte--tte-opera-festival-riverside-studios-londonthe-francis-bacon-opera-camden-arts-centre-london-8034577.html "The Francis Bacon Opera, Camden Arts Centre, London"]. ''[[The Independent]]''. Retrieved 1 March 2013. while Malcolm Jack in ''[[The Scotsman]]'' derided it as "silly, pretentious nonsense masquerading as experimental theatre."Jack, Malcolm (23 August 2012). [http://www.scotsman.com/the-scotsman/scotland/review-the-francis-bacon-opera-c-too-venue-4-1-2485246 "Review: The Francis Bacon Opera, C too (Venue 4)"]. ''[[The Scotsman]]''. Retrieved 1 March 2013. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *Stevenson, Martin (17 August 2012). [http://www.whatsonstage.com/news/theatre/london/E8831345409088/The+Francis+Bacon+Opera.html "Review: ''The Francis Bacon Opera'']. {{refimprove|date=December 2009}} '''The Susso''' is an Australian slang term referring to "sustenance" ([[welfare]]) payments, especially during the [[Great Depression in Australia|Great Depression]]. "Susso" could also be used as a noun, for someone depending on such payments,Ramson, W. S. ''The Australian National Dictionary'' p.652 Oxford University Press 1988 {{ISBN|0-19-554736-5}} often unsympathetically. ==Background== By late 1929, the economic depression had hit all western countries. == Causes == The prices of wool and wheat - two of the nation’s biggest exports had been in rapid decline. Overseas investments and loans started to disappear. As money became tight, there was a large decrease on spending on public work, which led to an increase in unemployment. The unemployment was further exacerbated by the falling income from primary producers. At the end of 1929, Australia's unemployment rate sat at around 13%. By 1932, it had peaked at a staggering 29%. == Effects == Though the downturn in the economy had a much greater effect on the lives of the poor, not even the very rich could ignore the situation, as evidence of the Depression could be found everywhere. It was seen in the [[Unemployment benefits#Australia|dole]] queues, [[Soup kitchen#History|soup kitchens]] doling out [[Staple food|staple]], filling foods, such as bread and potatoes, and [[shanty town]]s that sprang up across the nation. The Depression was illustrated by the estimated 40,000 homeless who had to create makeshift accommodation in public parks and fields and by the men that went wandering - "on the track" - in search of work during this time, or even food, known as [[swagmen]]. These men - estimated to be somewhere around 30,000 in numbers, had to report to a police station every week, where they could claim very basic rations of food. == The susso == By 1932, more than 60,000 people depended on sustenance payments - known as "the susso", merely to survive. This was only for the truly destitute, who had been unemployed for a sustained period of time, and had no assets or savings. Relief was State-based - in [[South Australia]] it was in the form of rations and vouchers.[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article55933644 A Wife Intervenes] ''The Mail (Adelaide)'' 7 August 1937 p.7 accessed 25 July 2011 At a time when the basic wage was £2/11/8d, "the susso" in [[Queensland]] was 3s. to 4/6d per child. "Many spend more than that on a dog", one speaker was quoted as saying.[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article41786529 Actual Poverty in Land of Plenty] ''Cairns Post'' Saturday 7 November 1936 p.6 accessed 25 July 2011
£2/11/8d and 3s. translate to around $800 and $45 in today's money. It was immortalised in a contemporary children’s rhyme (probably based on "[[You're in the Army Now (song)|You're in the Army Now]]", a [[World War I]] song featured in [[intertitles]] of the 1925 [[King Vidor]] silent film ''[[The Big Parade]]''): :"We’re on the susso now, :We can’t afford a cow, :We live in a tent, :We pay no rent, :We’re on the susso now."Carter, J. ''All Things Wild'' p.7 cited in ''The Australian National Dictionary'' Ed. W. S. Ramson, Oxford University Press 1988 {{ISBN|0-19-554736-5}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Susso}} [[Category:Great Depression]] [[Category:Slang]] [[Category:Welfare in Australia]] [[Category:Economic history of Australia]] [[Category:Social security in Australia]]

{{Infobox wrestling event |name=Triplemanía XXII |image=Triplemanía XXII.png |caption= |tagline= |promotion=[[Lucha Libre AAA Worldwide|AAA]] |date={{dts|2014|08|17}}<ref name=TMXXII>{{cite web | url = http://www.luchalibreaaa.com/carteleraaaa/item/1562-agosto-17-tripleman%C3%ADa-xxii-arena-ciudad-de-m%C3%A9xico-distrito-federal.html | title = Agosto 17 - Triplemanía XXII - Arena Ciudad de México, Distrito Federal | accessdate=July 26, 2014 | work=[[Lucha Libre AAA Worldwide|AAA]] | language=Spanish}}</ref><ref name=TMXXIIPWI>{{cite web | url = http://www.pwinsider.com/article/86309/the-lucha-report.html?p=1 | title = The Lucha Report | last=Zellner | first=Kris | date=June 16, 2014 | accessdate=July 26, 2014 | work=Pro Wrestling Insider}}</ref> |attendance=21,000<ref name=WONResults/> |venue=[[Mexico City Arena|Arena Ciudad de México]]<ref name=TMXXII/><ref name=TMXXIIPWI/> |city=[[Mexico City]]<ref name=TMXXII/><ref name=TMXXIIPWI/> |lastevent=[[Verano de Escándalo (2014)]] |nextevent=[[Héroes Inmortales VIII]] |event=[[Triplemanía]] |lastevent2=[[Triplemanía XXI]] |nextevent2=[[Triplemanía XXIII]] }} '''Triplemanía XXII''' was a [[professional wrestling]] [[pay-per-view]] (PPV) produced by the [[Lucha Libre AAA Worldwide|AAA]] [[Professional wrestling promotion|promotion]]. It took place on August 17, 2014, at [[Mexico City Arena|Arena Ciudad de México]] in [[Mexico City]], [[Mexico]]. The event was the twenty-second annual [[Triplemanía]], which is AAA's biggest show of the year, airing in Mexico as a regular PPV and internationally as an internet pay-per-view (iPPV). This was the first AAA PPV event to be broadcast simultaneously in English through SAP, having [[Hugo Savinovich]] and [[Vampiro]] as announcers.
[[Alberto Del Rio]], who was fired from [[WWE]] more than a week prior, made an appearance at the event. WWE wrestler [[Rey Mysterio]] also appeared in a video package to end the show. [[Jeff Jarrett]] and [[Ricochet (wrestler)|Ricochet]] were advertised for the event, but both missed the event due to travel issues.
==Production==
===Background=== In early 1992 [[Antonio Peña]] was working as a booker and storyline writer for [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] (CMLL), Mexico's largest and the world's oldest wrestling promotion, and was frustrated by CMLL's very conservative approach to ''[[lucha libre]]''. He joined forced with a number of younger, very talented wrestlers who felt like CMLL was not giving them recognition they deserved and decided to split from CMLL to create Asistencia Asesoría y Administración (AAA, or Triple A; Spanish for "Assistance, Consulting, and Administration" later renamed [[Lucha Libre AAA Worldwide|AAA]]). After making a deal with the ''Televisa'' television network AAA held their first show in April, 1992.<ref name=SLOrbit>{{cite web | url= http://superluchas.net/2006/10/07/el-fin-de-una-era/| title= El fin de una era| date= October 7, 2006 | accessdate= October 14, 2009 | author= Ocampo, Ernesto | publisher= ''SuperLuchas'' Magazine | language=Spanish}}</ref> The following year Peña and AAA held their first [[Triplemanía]] event, building it into an annual event that would become AAA's [[Super Bowl]] event, similar to the [[WWE]]'s [[WrestleMania]] being the biggest show of the year.<ref name=background>{{cite web|title=Triplemanía XXII será de nuevo en la Ciudad de México|url=http://www.mediotiempo.com/mas-deportes/lucha-libre/noticias/2014/02/18/triplemania-xxii-sera-de-nuevo-en-la-ciudad-de-mexico|accessdate=July 16, 2014|language=Spanish|website=mediotiempo.com|publisher=Grupo Expansión}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Madigan, Dan|title=Mondo Lucha Libre: the bizarre and honorable world of wild Mexican wrestling|publisher=HarperColins Publisher|year=2007|chapter=A family affair|pages=128–132|isbn=978-0-06-085583-3}}</ref> The 2014 Triplemanía was the 22nd year in a row AAA held a Triplemanía show and the 26th overall show under the Triplemanía banner. In February 2014, it was announced that Triplemanía XXII would be held in the [[Mexico City Arena|Arena Ciudad de México]] in [[Mexico City]], [[Mexico]], for the third consecutive year; this would be the eighth time that Mexico City would host Triplemanía.<ref name=background/>
There were multiple options to watch Triplemanía XXII: via traditional [[pay-per-view]] on the [[SKY México|SKY]] television service at $229 ([[Mexican peso]]) for [[Standard-definition television|standard-definition]] and $298 for [[High-definition television|high-definition]], or via Internet pay-per-view (iPPV) at $194.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Angelita|first1=Dark|title=AAA – Triplemania XXII: Los pormenores de la conferencia de prensa TMXXII|url=https://superluchas.com/2014/08/06/aaa-triplemania-xxii-los-pormenores-de-la-conferencia-de-prensa-tmxxii|language=Spanish|publisher=SuperLuchas|accessdate=July 16, 2015}}</ref> This would be the seventh year Triplemanía would be available through SKY. The iPPV was available on AAA's official website, www.luchalibreaaa.com.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Angelita|first1=Dark|title=La edición 22 de Triplemania en PPV por SKY y por Internet|url=https://superluchas.com/2014/07/29/aaa-triplemania-xxii-podra-ser-vista-en-pago-por-evento-y-por-ippv/|publisher=SuperLuchas|accessdate=July 16, 2015|language=Spanish}}</ref> This was the promotion's first iPPV in a year after problems arose when [[Triplemanía XXI]] was shown on iPPV.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.wrestleview.com/featured-articles/49302-feature-viva-la-raza-lucha-weekly-for-6-28-14 | title = Viva la Raza! Lucha Weekly for 6/28/14 | last=Boutwell | first=Josh | date=June 28, 2014 | accessdate=July 26, 2014 | work=Wrestleview}}</ref>
===Storylines=== The Triplemanía XXII show featured six [[Professional wrestling match types|professional wrestling matches]] with different wrestlers involved in pre-existing [[Screenplay|scripted]] feuds, [[plot (narrative)|plots]] and [[narrative thread|storylines]]. Wrestlers were portrayed as either [[Heel (professional wrestling)|heels]] (referred to as ''rudos'' in Mexico, those that portray the "bad guys") or [[Face (professional wrestling)|faces]] (''técnicos'' in Mexico, the "good guy" characters) as they followed a series of tension-building events, which culminated in a wrestling match or series of matches.
AAA frequently has eight person tag team matches open their major events, usually featuring on each team a high-flying wrestler, a female ''luchadora'', an [[exótico]] (in [[Drag (clothing)|drag]]) and a ''[[Mini-Estrella]]''. The opening match for Triplemanía XXII featured two feuds, one between former team-mates of the [[Real Fuerza Aérea]] faction, [[Aero Star]] and [[Súper Fly]], and another feud between [[Pimpinela Escarlata]] and [[Mamba (wrestler)|Mamba]].<ref name=WVpre>{{cite web|title=Feature: Josh Boutwell previews Triplemania XXII TONIGHT|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/featured-articles/50216|website=wrestleview.com|accessdate=July 12, 2015}}</ref><ref name=AAApreview>{{cite web|title=Triplemania XXII: Cartel Completo|url=http://www.luchalibreaaa.com/noticiasaaa/item/1629-tripleman%C3%ADa-xxii-cartel-completo.html|accessdate=July 13, 2015|language=Spanish}}</ref>
The second match on the card had a complicated buildup. Bengala won an elimination match to become the number one contender to Daga's AAA Cruiserweight Championship. However, after AAA Fusión Champion Fenix pinned Daga in a six-man tag team match, Fenix also wanted to challenge for Daga's title, and he was willing to put his own title on the line at the same time. Daga agreed to the title challenges, after-which a multi-man elimination match to unify the AAA Cruiserweight and AAA Fusión Championship was set up for Triplemanía XXII, with several other wrestlers added to the match as well; those being [[Angélico]], Australian Suicide, [[El Hijo del Fantasma]], [[Jack Evans (wrestler)|Jack Evans]], [[Joe Líder]], [[Pentagón Jr]] and [[Ricochet (wrestler)|Ricochet]].<ref name=WVpre/>
The third match, for the [[AAA Reina de Reinas Championship]], was set up when [[Taya Valkyrie|Taya]] won a number one contender elimination match in June 2014 over [[Cynthia Moreno]], La Jarochita, La Magnifica, [[Mari Apache]], Sexy Lady and [[Sexy Star]]. Taya was described to have been feuding with champion [[Faby Apache]] "for quite some time".<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.wrestleview.com/featured-articles/48892-feature-viva-la-raza-lucha-weekly-for-6-7-14|title=Feature: Viva La Raza! Lucha Weekly for 6/7/14|last=Boutwell|first=Josh|date=June 7, 2014|accessdate=July 13, 2015|work=wrestleview.com}}</ref>
The fourth match, where the last wrestler to escape the cage would lose his mask or hair, had little buildup. The storyline leading into the match was [[Jeff Jarrett]]'s rivalry against Mexican wrestlers. [[Blue Demon Jr]], [[Electroshock (wrestler)|Electro Shock]] and La Parka represented the ''técnicos'' of ''Ejercito AAA'', while [[Averno (wrestler)|Averno]], [[Chessman (wrestler)|Chessman]] and Jarrett being the ''rudos''.<ref name=WVpre/><ref name=AAApreview/><ref>{{cite web|last1=Valdés|first1=Apolo|title=El cartel de Triplemanía XXII|url=http://www.mediotiempo.com/mas-deportes/lucha-libre/editoriales/apolo-valdes/2014/08/el-cartel-de-triplemania-xxii|website=mediotiempo.com|publisher=Grupo Expansión|accessdate=July 16, 2015|language=Spanish}}</ref> To set up the match, Jarrett attacked Electro Shock with a guitar and drew blood in [[Querétaro]] in June 2014.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Angelita|first1=Dark|title=AAA – Triplemanía XXII: Lo que se espera de la Lucha en jaula|url=https://superluchas.com/2014/07/31/aaa-triplemania-xxii-lo-que-se-espera-de-la-lucha-en-jaula|publisher=SuperLuchas|accessdate=July 16, 2015|language=Spanish}}</ref>
The four-way match originally promoted as second to the main event was for the Copa Triplemanía XXII, and also featured little buildup. This would be [[Myzteziz]]'s first major event for AAA since his in-ring debut, and he would once again face one of his hottest rivals, [[Perro Aguayo Jr.]] AAA announced a surprise entrant for the match, which was revealed as [[Dr. Wagner Jr.]] in his return to the promotion. Wagner Jr. started a rivalry with the final entrant, [[Cibernético]], heading into the match.<ref name=WVpre/><ref name=AAApreview/>
For the match originally promoted as the main event, the feud between [[Psycho Clown]] and [[Texano Jr.]] began due to the rivalry between their respective factions, ''Los Psycho Circus'' and ''El Consejo''.<ref name=WVpre/> Psycho Clown had twice challenged for Texano Jr's [[AAA Mega Championship]], but lost twice due to the referees cheating on behalf of Texano Jr.<ref name=WVpre/><ref name=AAApreview/> Despite the AAA Mega Championship not being on the line at Triplemanía XXII, the meeting of the duo was described as "the ultimate match of respect between luchadors" due to the ''[[Lucha de Apuestas]]'' conditions, where the loser must forfeit his hair (for Texano Jr) or his mask (for Psycho Clown).<ref name=WVpre/><ref name=AAApreview/> The feud was seen as a continuation of the historical feud between ''[[Alvarado wrestling family|Los Brazos]]'' and ''[[Los Misioneros de la Muerte]]'', as Psycho Clown is a descendant of [[Brazo de Plata]] of the Alvarado Nieves generation, while Texano Jr. is the son of [[El Texano]].<ref>{{cite web|author1=El Memo Pacheco|title=Texano Jr. vs Psycho Clown: Misioneros vs Brazos versión moderna|url=https://superluchas.com/2014/07/21/texano-jr-vs-psycho-clown-misioneros-vs-brazos-version-moderna/|publisher=SuperLuchas|accessdate=July 16, 2015|language=Spanish}}</ref>
[[Alberto Del Rio]] was fired by [[WWE]] on August 7, 2014, with the promotion citing his "unprofessional conduct and an altercation with an employee".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Oster|first1=Aaron|title=WWE fires Alberto Del Rio|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2014-08-08/sports/bal-wwe-fires-alberto-del-rio-aaa-20140807_1_sheamus-alberto-del-rio-cm-punk|work=[[The Baltimore Sun]]|accessdate=July 13, 2015}}</ref> [[Dave Meltzer]] of ''The Wrestling Observer'' reported that "the story going around" was that Del Rio had slapped a manager of [[social media]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Meltzer|first1=Dave|title=WWE News: More details on Alberto Del Rio firing|url=http://www.f4wonline.com/more/more-top-stories/96-wwe/38362|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150713180318/http://www.f4wonline.com/more/more-top-stories/96-wwe/38362|website=f4wonline.com|archivedate=July 13, 2015|accessdate=July 13, 2015}}</ref> Del Rio later said that he reacted to what he felt was a racist comment by a fellow employee by demanding an apology. When the employee responded by smiling, Del Rio slapped him. Del Rio was later ashamed of his reaction but vowed to uphold his own dignity.<ref>{{cite web|title=Fui víctima de racismo: Alberto del Río|url=http://www.mediotiempo.com/mas-deportes/lucha-libre/noticias/2014/08/16/fui-victima-de-racismo-alberto-del-rio|accessdate=July 22, 2015|website=mediotiempo.com|publisher=Grupo Expansión}}</ref> Additionally, WWE's [[Twitter]] account released a message stating that Del Rio "is responsible for his own actions. If you're angry at anyone, be angry at Alberto. There's no excuse for a pro athlete not to conduct themselves in a professional manner."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Caldwell|first1=James|title=WWE calls out Alberto Del Rio post-release|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/WWE_News_3/article_80053.shtml|website=pwtorch.com|accessdate=13 July 2015}}</ref> Less than a week after the firing, Del Rio was announced to appear at Triplemanía XXII,<ref>{{cite web|title=Rey Mysterio update|url=http://www.pwinsider.com/ViewArticle.php?id=87557|website=pwinsider.com|accessdate=July 13, 2015}}</ref> but not wrestle, due to a 90-day non-compete clause imposed by WWE.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gutiérrez|first1=Emmanuel|title=Cláusula impediría a Alberto del Río luchar en Triplemanía XXII|url=http://www.mediotiempo.com/mas-deportes/lucha-libre/noticias/2014/08/14/clausula-impediria-a-alberto-del-rio-luchar-en-triplemania-xxii|website=mediotiempo.com|publisher=Grupo Expansión|accessdate=July 16, 2014}}</ref> Del Rio previously took part in [[Triplemanía X]] in 2002, as Dos Caras Jr.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://luchalibreaaa.com/noticiasaaa/item/1653-alberto-del-r%C3%ADo-en-tripleman%C3%ADa-xxii.html|title=Alberto del Río en Triplemanía XXII|date=August 11, 2014|accessdate=August 12, 2014|work=[[Lucha Libre AAA Worldwide|AAA]]|language=Spanish}}</ref>
==Event== Triplemanía began with the returning Alberto Del Rio, billed as El Patron Alberto talking about his departure from WWE and the racism within it, before he was interrupted by [[Konnan]] and [[El Hijo del Perro Aguayo]] A physical altercation occurred starting with El Patron's father, [[Dos Caras]], being assaulted, but El Patron fended off the attackers. In another non-match event, the AAA Hall of Fame welcomed new inductees [[El Brazo]] and [[Rayo de Jalisco Sr.]]; with the ceremony being interrupted by El Hjo del Perro Aguayo. Meanwhile, Jeff Jarett and Ricochet both missed the event despite being slated to wrestle, with both apologizing for having problems with their airline providers.<ref name=InsiderResults>{{cite web|title=Complete AAA Triplemania results and more: the Lucha Report|url=http://www.pwinsider.com/ViewArticle.php?id=87676|website=pwinsider.com|accessdate=July 12, 2015}}</ref><ref name=ESPN>{{cite web|last1=López|first1=Adrián|title="Perra" noche en Triplemania XXII|url=http://www.espn.com.co/news/story/_/id/2158139/perra-noche-en-triplemania-xxii|publisher=[[ESPN Latin America]]|accessdate=July 23, 2015}}</ref>
Aero Star's team won the opening match when Mascarita Sagrada submitted Mini Abismo Negro.<ref name=ViewResults/>
The order of elimination for the second match was firstly [[Drago (wrestler)|Drago]] (substituting for Ricochet), Jack Evans, Joe Lider, Australian Suicide, Bengala, Pentagon Jr, (AAA Fusión Champion) Fenix and then (AAA Cruiserweight Champion) Daga. Finally, Hijo del Fantasma used a variant of a piledriver on Angelico to win the match and the new AAA World Cruiserweight Championship.<ref name=InsiderResults/><ref name=AAAresults>{{cite web|title=Triplemania XXII: Noche De Leyenda|url=http://www.luchalibreaaa.com/eventos-magnos/triplemania/item/1659-noche-de-leyenda-en-tripleman%C3%ADa-xxii.html|accessdate=July 13, 2015|work=[[Lucha Libre AAA Worldwide|AAA]]|language=Spanish}}</ref><ref name=SuperResults>{{cite web|last1=Vela|first1=Eduardo Cano|title=AAA Triplemania 22 (Cobertura y resultados 17/8/14)|url=https://superluchas.com/2014/08/17/aaa-triplemania-22-cobertura-y-resultados-17814-alberto-el-patron-llega-aaa/|publisher=SuperLuchas|accessdate=July 22, 2015}}</ref>
The third match saw Taya defeating Fabi Apache to capture Apache's AAA Reina de Reinas Championship after a [[Northern Lights suplex]], a [[Professional wrestling attacks#Stomp|stomp variant]], and help from ''rudo'' referee Hijo del Tirantes. The match was described as "full of screwiness" due to Tirantes, Sexy Star and Hijo del Fantasma. Valkyrie, the first foreigner to win this title, suffered a broken nose in this match.<ref name=InsiderResults/><ref name=ViewResults/><ref name=AAAresults/><ref name=SuperResults/>
The fourth match saw Electroshock losing his hair as he lost a steel cage match when El Mesias (substituting for Jeff Jarrett, in his return after a near-eight month absence) escaped the cage after using a double knee backbreaker from the top rope on Electroshock. Prior to that, the order of escape was first La Parka Jr, then Averno, Blue Demon Jr, and Chessman. The match was described as "a total bloodbath full of wild spots".<ref name=InsiderResults/><ref>{{cite web|last1=Angelita|first1=Dark|title=AAA – "Me siento muy feliz de regresar de nuevo a mi casa": El Mesías|url=https://superluchas.com/2014/08/25/aaa-siento-muy-feliz-de-regresar-de-nuevo-mi-casa-el-mesias/|publisher=SuperLuchas|accessdate=July 16, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Electroshock rapado, no libró 'La Jaula' ante El Mesías|url=http://www.mediotiempo.com/mas-deportes/lucha-libre/noticias/2014/08/18/electroshock-rapado-no-libro-la-jaula-ante-el-mesias|accessdate=July 22, 2015|first1=Emmanuel|last1=Gutiérrez|website=mediotiempo.com|publisher=Grupo Expansión|language=Spanish}}</ref>
The fifth match resulted in Texano Jr.being shaved of his hair in the ring after losing to Psycho Clown, who pinned him after a ''[[Flip piledriver|Canadian Destroyer]]'' of the top rope through a table. Texano Jr.enjoyed help from Rafael "El Maya" and Hijo del Fantasma, forcing AAA's commissioner Fantasma to expel them from the ringside area. The match was described as "another bloodbath full of table spots and unprotected chair shots to the head". AAA described the result being that Psycho Clown "rompió la maldición de [[Alvarado wrestling family|los Alvarado]]" (broke the curse of Alvarado).<ref name=InsiderResults/><ref name=ViewResults/><ref name=AAAresults/> The feud ended with a handshake between the duo.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Vela|first1=Eduardo Cano|title=Psycho Clown rapa a Texano Jr.en AAA Triplemania 22|url=https://superluchas.com/2014/08/17/texano-jr-rapado-en-aaa-triplemania-22/|accessdate=July 16, 2015}}</ref>
The main event four-way elimination match saw blood from Dr Wagner Jr.and Mysteziz. Cibernetico eliminated Dr Wagner Jr.first after a chokeslam. Then, Mysteziz submitted Cibernetico by applying La Mistica. Finally, Perro Aguayo Jr.[[Professional wrestling attacks#Low blow|low blow]]ed Mysteziz to win the Copa Triplemanía XXII. After the match, El Patron stormed the ring to brawl with Perro Aguayo Jr; with El Patron emerging from the brawl dominant.<ref name=InsiderResults/><ref name=ViewResults/><ref>{{cite web|title=Triplemania Notes: Alberto Del Rio appears, Rey Mysterio video|url=http://www.f4wonline.com/more/more-top-stories/101-mexico/38525|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150713090120/http://www.f4wonline.com/more/more-top-stories/101-mexico/38525|archivedate=July 13, 2015|accessdate=July 13, 2015}}</ref>
The show ended with a video of Rey Mysterio (still contracted to WWE at the time) stating that he would return to AAA "soon".<ref name=InsiderResults/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/WWE_News_3/article_80274.shtml|title=Triplemania news: Current WWE star Mysterio teases jump to AAA, Del Rio talks racism in first post-WWE promo|date=August 18, 2014|accessdate=August 18, 2014|work=Pro Wrestling Torch}}</ref>
==Reception== 21,000 people attended the event in the [[Mexico City Arena|Arena Ciudad de México]].<ref name=TMXXII/><ref name=TMXXIIPWI/><ref name=WONResults/>
Josh Boutwell of wrestleview.com praised the opener as "very good", the Cruiserweight title match as "a great, high flying match with tons of action", and the Mask vs. Hair match as "awesome". However, Boutwell was critical of the cage match as "a disaster from the start" and the commentators including Vampiro, which Boutwell described as "one of the worst commentators in the history of wrestling". Lastly, Boutwell blasted the iPPV's "horrible stream" where he "was never able to see more than 1 minute uninterrupted of the stream before [he] gave up on the live show. It is beyond pathetic that after an entire year from the horrible disaster of last year's TripleMania stream this happens."<ref name=ViewResults/>
Adrián López of ESPN.com gave his views on some of the matches, stating that the main event showed the hatred between the competitors, while the penultimate match was an epic struggle and the women's match was dramatic, vibrant and exciting.<ref name=ESPN/>
==Aftermath== Triplemanía XXII was Perro Aguayo Jr's final Triplemanía event, as he died in late March 2015 at the age of 35. Aguayo Jr. died after wrestling a match in Tijuana, Mexico for a promotion called The Crash; he was teaming with [[T.J. Perkins|Manik]] against [[Tigre Uno|Extreme Tiger]] and Rey Mysterio Jr. Initial reports stated that the cause of death was cervical spine trauma at the neck.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Mullen|first1=Jethro|title=Mexican wrestling star Hijo del Perro Aguayo dies after kick in ring|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/03/22/americas/mexico-wrestling-hijo-del-perro-aguayo-death/|publisher=[[CNN]]|accessdate=July 13, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.f4wonline.com/more/more-top-stories/101-mexico/41727 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402113343/http://www.f4wonline.com/more/more-top-stories/101-mexico/41727 | title=Perro Aguayo Jr. passes away in Tijuana hospital after match last night (Updated) | archivedate=April 2, 2015 | date=March 21, 2015 | accessdate=July 13, 2015 | work=[[Wrestling Observer Newsletter]]}}</ref>
El Patrón Alberto had his first return match for AAA on September 14, 2014 in a six-man tag match, teaming with La Parka and Myzteziz to defeat [[Averno (wrestler)|Averno]], Perro Aguayo Jr.and Texano Jr.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://luchalibreaaa.com/resultados/item/1721-hard-rock-hotel-riviera-maya.html | title = Resultados de Ring & Rock StAAArs 3, Quintana Roo | accessdate=July 13, 2015 | work=[[Lucha Libre AAA Worldwide|AAA]]|language=Spanish}}</ref> On December 7, 2014 at [[Guerra de Titanes (2014)|Guerra de Titanes]], Alberto defeated Texano Jr.to win the [[AAA Mega Championship]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://superluchas.net/2014/12/07/el-patron-es-el-nuevo-megacampeon-de-aaa/|title=El Patrón es el nuevo Megacampeón de AAA|last=Hernandez|first=Kennedy|date=December 7, 2014|accessdate=July 13, 2015|work=SuperLuchas|language=Spanish}}</ref>
Also at Guerra de Titanes, Aero Star defeated Super Fly and thus forced him to unmask; Super Fly's real name was revealed as Erick Aguilar Muñoz.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mediotiempo.com/mas-deportes/lucha-libre/noticias/2014/12/07/aerostar-desenmascaro-a-super-fly|title=Aerostar desenmascaró a Súper Fly|date=December 7, 2014|accessdate=July 13, 2014|website=mediotiempo.com|publisher=Grupo Expansión|language=Spanish}}</ref>
It was announced in early March 2015 that Rey Mysterio Jr. had joined AAA;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/Other_News_4/article_83656.shtml|title=AAA news: Rey Mysterio officially joins AAA in Mexico|last=Caldwell|first=James|date=March 3, 2015|accessdate=March 4, 2015|work=Pro Wrestling Torch}}</ref> he would have his return match for AAA later that month.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.luchalibreaaa.com/noticiasaaa/item/2097-cartel-completo-rey-de-reyes-2015.html | title=Cartel Completo: Rey de Reyes 2015 | publisher=Lucha Libre AAA World Wide | language=Spanish | accessdate=July 13, 2015}}</ref>
After losing his hair, Electroshock teased retiring from professional wrestling.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.mediotiempo.com/mas-deportes/lucha-libre/noticias/2014/10/22/electro-shock-con-el-futuro-incierto | title = Electro Shock, con el futuro incierto | date=October 22, 2014 | accessdate=February 13, 2015 | website=mediotiempo.com | publisher=Grupo Expansión | language=Spanish}}</ref> However, Electroshock instead went to form a new faction in 2015 called ''Holocausto'', this group included [[El Hijo de Pirata Morgan]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.mediotiempo.com/mas-deportes/lucha-libre/noticias/2015/05/27/campeonato-de-tercias-aaa-en-fuego | title = Campeonato de Tercias AAA, en fuego | date=May 27, 2015 | accessdate=July 13, 2015 | website=mediotiempo.com | publisher=Grupo Expansión | language=Spanish}}</ref>

{{RTGS|''watsa''}} | bo = | bo-Latn = | vi = | id = }} {{Contains Indic text}} {{Buddhism}} '''Vassa''' ({{lang-pi|vassa-|script=Latn}}, {{lang-sa|varṣa-|script=Latn}}, both "rain") is the three-month annual [[Retreat (spiritual)|retreat]] observed by [[Theravada]] practitioners. Taking place during the [[wet season]], Vassa lasts for three [[lunar month]]s, usually from July (the [[Burmese calendar|Burmese month]] of Waso, {{my|ဝါဆို}}) to October (the Burmese month of Thadingyut {{my|သီတင်းကျွတ်}}).[http://buddhism.about.com/od/buddhismglossaryv/g/Vassadef.htm Vassa] at [[About.com]] In English, Vassa is often glossed as '''Rains Retreat'''{{Cite web |url=http://www.experiencefestival.com/a/Vassa/id/578909 |title=Vassa |access-date=2010-10-14 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100323201202/http://www.experiencefestival.com/a/Vassa/id/578909 |archive-date=2010-03-23 |dead-url=yes |df= }} or '''Buddhist Lent''',{{cite news|url=http://www.mmtimes.com/no427/n003.htm|title=Shwedagon Pagoda marks the start of Buddhist Lent this week|last=Thein|first=Cherry|date=July 14–20, 2008|work=The Myanmar Times|accessdate=15 July 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110921104822/http://www.mmtimes.com/no427/n003.htm|archive-date=21 September 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} the latter by analogy to the [[Lent|Christian Lent]] (which Vassa predates by at least five centuries). For the duration of Vassa, monastics remain in one place, typically a [[monastery|monasteries]] or temple grounds.[http://www.accesstoinsight.org/lib/authors/khantipalo/wheel206.html#rains Lay Buddhist Practice - The Shrine Room, Uposatha Day, Rains Residence][http://www.bookrags.com/tandf/was-vassa-tf/ Was (Thai) Vassa] In some monasteries, monks dedicate the Vassa to intensive [[meditation]]. Some Buddhist lay people choose to observe Vassa by adopting more ascetic practices, such as giving up meat, alcohol, or smoking. While Vassa is sometimes casually called "Buddhist [[Lent]]", others object to this terminology. Commonly, the number of years a monk has spent in monastic life is expressed by counting the number of vassas (or ''rains'') since [[upasampada|ordination]]. Most [[Mahayana]] Buddhists do not observe Vassa, though [[Vietnamese Thiền]] and [[Korean Seon]] monastics observe an equivalent retreat of three months of intensive practice in one location, a practice also observed in [[Tibetan Buddhism]]. Vassa begins on the first day of the waning moon of the eighth lunar month, which is the day after [[Asalha Puja]] or Asalha [[Uposatha]] ("Dhamma day"). It ends on [[Pavarana]], when all monastics come before the [[Sangha (Buddhism)|sangha]] and atone for any offense that might have been committed during Vassa. Vassa is followed by [[Kathina]], a festival in which the [[Upāsaka and Upāsikā|laity]] expresses gratitude to monks.[http://www.viet.net/~anson/ebud/ebdha086.htm Vassa (Rains Retreat) and Kathina (Robe Offering) Ceremony][http://www.buddhistchannel.tv/index.php?id=6,9375,0,0,1,0 Vassa, The Rains Retreat] Lay Buddhists bring donations to temples, especially new robes for the monks.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/religion/religions/buddhism/holydays/kathina.shtml Kathina] at [[BBC]] The Vassa tradition predates the time of [[Gautama Buddha]]. It was a long-standing custom for [[sramana|mendicant ascetics]] in India not to travel during the rainy season as they may unintentionally harm crops, insects or even themselves during their travels. Many Buddhist ascetics live in regions which lack a rainy season. Consequently, there are places where Vassa may not be typically observed. == See also == * [[Wan Ok Phansa]] * [[Uposatha]] * [[Thai lunar calendar|Thai Lunar Calendar]] * [[Ango]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Commons category|Vassa}} {{Buddhism topics}} [[Category:Festivals in Thailand]] [[Category:Pali words and phrases]] [[Category:Buddhist festivals]] [[Category:Festivals in India]] [[Category:Non-Gregorian July observances]] [[Category:Non-Gregorian August observances]] [[Category:Non-Gregorian September observances]] [[Category:Non-Gregorian October observances]] [[Category:Observances set by the Burmese calendar]] [[Category:Spiritual retreats]] [[Category:Buddhist terminology]]

{{Confusing|reason=Examples, instead of using the YPLL as defined, show the value YPLL × 100000 or use different undefined terms such as 'Person Years Lost' or YLL|date=May 2016}} '''Years of potential life lost''' ('''YPLL''') or '''potential years of life lost''' ('''PYLL'''), is an estimate of the [[average]] years a person would have lived if he or she had not died prematurely.<ref name=homes>{{cite web|author=Gardner JW|author2=Sanborn JS |url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?db=pubmed&list_uids=2083312&cmd=Retrieve&indexed=google|title=Years of potential life lost (YPLL)—what does it measure?|accessdate=2006-12-14}}</ref> It is, therefore, a measure of premature [[death|mortality]]. As an alternative to [[mortality rate|death rates]], it is a method that gives more weight to deaths that occur among younger people. An alternative is to consider the effects of both disability and premature death using [[disability adjusted life years]].
== Calculation ==
To calculate the years of potential life lost, the analyst has to set an upper reference age. The reference age should correspond roughly to the life expectancy of the population under study. In the developed world, this is commonly set at age 75, but it is essentially arbitrary. Thus, PYLL should be written with respect to the reference age used in the calculation: e.g., PYLL[75].
PYLL can be calculated using individual level data or using age grouped data.<ref>{{cite web|last=Association of Public Health Epidemiologists in Ontario |title=Calculating Potential Years of Life Lost (PYLL) |url=http://www.apheo.ca/index.php?pid=190 |accessdate=2008-05-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706164746/http://www.apheo.ca/index.php?pid=190 |archivedate=July 6, 2011 }}</ref>
Briefly, for the individual method, each person's PYLL is calculated by subtracting the person's age at death from the reference age. If a person is older than the reference age when he or she dies, that person's PYLL is set to zero (i.e., there are no "negative" PYLLs). In effect, only those who die before the reference age are included in the calculation. Some examples:
# Reference age = 75; Age at death = 60; PYLL[75] = 75 − 60 = 15 # Reference age = 75; Age at death = 6 months; PYLL[75] = 75 − 0.5 = 74.5 # Reference age = 75; Age at death = 80; PYLL[75] = 0 (age at death greater than reference age)
To calculate the PYLL for a particular population in a particular year, the analyst sums the individual PYLLs for all individuals in that population who died in that year. This can be done for all-cause mortality or for cause-specific mortality.
== Significance ==
In the developed world, mortality counts and rates tend to emphasise the most common causes of death in older people because the risk of death increases with age. Because PYLL gives more weight to deaths among younger people, it is the favoured metric among those who wish to draw attention to those causes of death that are more common in younger people. Some researchers say that this measurement should be considered by governments when they decide how best to divide up scarce resources for research.<ref name="pmid15655548">{{cite journal |vauthors=Burnet NG, Jefferies SJ, Benson RJ, Hunt DP, Treasure FP |title=Years of life lost (YLL) from cancer is an important measure of population burden—and should be considered when allocating research funds |journal=Br. J. Cancer |volume=92 |issue=2 |pages=241–5 |date=January 2005 |pmid=15655548 |pmc=2361853 |doi=10.1038/sj.bjc.6602321 |url=}}</ref>
For example, in most of the developed world, heart disease and cancer are the leading causes of death, as measured by the number (or rate) of deaths. For this reason, heart disease and cancer tend to get a lot of attention (and research funding). However, one might argue that everyone has to die of something eventually, and so public health efforts should be more explicitly directed at preventing ''premature'' death. When PYLL is used as an explicit measure of premature death, then injuries and infectious diseases, become more important. While the most common cause of death of young people aged 5 to 40 is injury and poisoning in the developed world, because relatively few young people die, the principal causes of lost years remain [[Cardiovascular disease| cardiovascular disease]] and cancer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mhcs.health.nsw.gov.au/pubs/2008/pdf/chorep_summary_08.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-01-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090121024116/http://mhcs.health.nsw.gov.au/pubs/2008/pdf/chorep_summary_08.pdf |archivedate=2009-01-21 |df= }}Page 54 Retrieved 17 January 2009.</ref>

===Australia=== The report of the NSW Chief Medical Officer in 2002 indicates that cardiovascular disease (32.7% (of total Males Years of Life Lost due to premature mortality) and 36.6% of females YLL) and [[malignant neoplasm]]s (27.5% of Males YLL and 31.2% of Females YLL) are the main causes of lost years <ref>{{cite web |url=http://mhcs.health.nsw.gov.au/public-health/chorep02/bod/bod_YLLcateg.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-01-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20070613213424/http://mhcs.health.nsw.gov.au/public-health/chorep02/bod/bod_YLLcateg.htm |archivedate=13 June 2007 |df= }} Retrieved=17 January 2009</ref>
When [[disability adjusted life years]] are considered, [[cancer]] (25.1/1,000), [[cardiovascular disease]] (23.8/1,000), [[mental health]] issues (17.6/1,000), [[neurological disorders]] (15.7/1,000), chronic [[respiratory disease]] (9.4/1,000) and [[diabetes]] (7.2/1,000) are the main causes of good years of expected life lost to disease or premature death.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mhcs.health.nsw.gov.au/pubs/2008/pdf/chorep_summary_08.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-01-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090121024116/http://mhcs.health.nsw.gov.au/pubs/2008/pdf/chorep_summary_08.pdf |archivedate=2009-01-21 |df= }}Retrieved=17 January 2009 Page 53</ref> The dramatic difference is in the greater number of years of disability caused [[mental illness]] and neurological issues and by [[diabetes]].
